This two week tailor made tour invites an extra special glimpse at the wildlife and beautiful national parks of Southern India. From Nagarahole and Bandipur to Mudumalai and Eravikulam, this is an itinerary that leaves no stone unturned when it comes to experiencing exciting big game areas.

Periyar Tiger Reserve is one of many incredible highlights with chances to also spot wild deer, flamingos, elephants and leopards, adding to the chance of seeing tigers in their natural habitat.

After all these wild adventures amongst the jungle trails of India, it makes sense to have some time to reflect. Where better than the backwaters of Kerala from where you can round your fabulous fortnight off in style from the sun-kissed deck of a traditional houseboat – ah, bliss!

dayInfo.description: After arriving in Bangalore, you will be met at the airport and transferred to your hotel. You have the option of a city tour, or just relax as tomorrow we have an exciting journey to the beautiful jungles of south India.

We leave Bangalore after breakfast and drive to Nagarhole National Park, which is about 5 hours away. Nagarhole is a part of the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve and is among India’s best national parks. Its rich, varied wildlife includes the Tiger, Leopard, Indian Bison, Sloth Bear, Gaur, Sambar Deer, Chital, Common Muntjac and almost 250 species of birds. The park is best known for its large population of Elephants. We arrive at Nagarhole around noon, in time for lunch. After lunch, we set out for our first game drive into the park and will stay inside the park until dusk. We will be spending two nights at Nagarhole.

We begin the day with an early morning game drive into the Nagarahole forest. During the game drive, you will get a glimpse of the park’s unspoiled beauty. Mornings are the best time to sight animals and you are likely to see herds of Elephants on the banks of the river. After the game drive, we return to the lodge for breakfast. Once you finish breakfast, you can take a nature walk and explore the beautiful flora of the park. We return to the lodge for lunch and after lunch, we set out once again to explore Nagarahole.

After an early morning game safari and breakfast at Nagarahole, we head out to Bandipur National Park, which is about 3 hours drive from Nagarhole. Bandipur National Park is one of the best-known protected areas in India and is also a Project Tiger reserve. The park is famous for its Bengal Tigers, Asian Elephants and for the abundance of sandalwood trees. In addition, it is also home to Leopards, Sloth Bears, Panthers, Chevrotains, Dholes (Wild Dogs), Hyenas, Gaur, Wild Boar, Sambar Deer, Chital, Barking Deer and Mouse Deer. On arrival in Bandipur, we check in to our lodge and have lunch. This is followed by a game drive into the park. Bandipur National Park is one of the best-known protected areas in India and is also a Project Tiger reserve. The park is famous for its Bengal Tigers, Asian Elephants and for the abundance of sandalwood trees. In addition, it is also home to Leopards, Sloth Bears, Panthers, Chevrotains, Dholes (Wild Dogs), Hyenas, Gaur, Sambar (Deer), Chital, Wild Boar, Barking Deer and Mouse Deer.

Today, we go on a morning game drive into Bandipur and return to the lodge for breakfast. This is followed by a game drive into the park. Bandipur National Park is one of the best-known protected areas in India and is also a Project Tiger reserve. The park is famous for its Bengal Tigers, Asian Elephants and for the abundance of sandalwood trees. In addition, it is also home to Leopards, Sloth Bears, Panthers, Chevrotains, Dholes (Wild Dogs), Hyenas, Gaur, Sambar (Deer), Chital, Wild Boar, Barking Deer and Mouse Deer.

Today is our last day at Bandipur and we go for a game drive in the morning and return to the lodge for breakfast. We then drive for about 8 hours to reach Munnar, stopping on the way for lunch. Munnar is a beautiful town up in the hills, best known for the tea grown here. The tea, which has a delicate flavor of cardamom, can be used to brew the famous Indian 'Chai'! (Tea), Munnar also offers a splendid view of pristine valleys and mountains, exotic species of flora and fauna, and the aroma of cool, spice-scented air! You can spend the evening relaxing and enjoying the lovely weather and the spectacular view.

Today we visit the Eravikulam National Park. We carry a picnic lunch with us. As vehicles are not allowed inside the park, we explore the area on foot. After a whole day at Eravikulam, we return to our hotel in the evening for dinner. Eravikulam was established to protect the Nilgiri Tahr, an endangered species of mountain goat. It is the only mountain goat species found south of the Himalayas. Sure-footed herds of Tahr are quite elusive, but you may be able to get a good view of them as they browse the hillside vegetation. Eravikulam is also home to a variety of mammals that include the Nilgiri Langur, Lion-tailed Macaque and several endemic bird species such as the streaky brown Nilgiri Pipit and Blackbird. The Blackbird in particular looks very different from the familiar songster of Europe and is regarded by some taxonomists as a possible separate species. Note: Eravikulam National Park remains Closed from Mid of Jan – Mid of April

After breakfast, we embark on a three hour drive to reach the Aranya Niwas Hotel in Periyar. The hotel is located inside the Tiger Reserve in the Cardamom Hills. We visit the spice gardens for which the area is well known. Since the olden times, spices were traded like gold in India and you see why...the cardamom and the pepper grown here has a superb aroma! We return to the hotel at dusk and end the day with dinner. Periyar is one of the Project Tiger Reserves of India. It is one of the most picturesque and beautiful wildlife reserves in the world. In addition to the Tiger, Periyar is also home to the Indian Elephant, Gaur, Sambar (Horse Deer), Barking Deer, Mouse Deer, Dhole (Indian Wild Dog), Fox, Leopard and the elusive Nilgiri Tahr.

Start the day with a boat ride on the Periyar Lake. It is the best time to spot birds and do keep an eye out for the Flamingos! After the boat ride, we return to the lodge for breakfast. Walking is the best way to explore the Park and you get to see some of the smaller animals, insects and monkeys when you are on foot...we do precisely this and walk in the forest till lunch time. You have the rest of the day to yourself, you can either relax or spend the day exploring the serene surroundings (with optional activities including – bamboo rafting, border hiking.)
Optional activities available from the hotel: Boat ride, Walking Bamboo Rafting, Border Hiking

After an early morning boat ride and breakfast in Periyar, we drive to Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary, which is about 4 ½ hours by road. Situated in the backwaters of Kerala, Kumarakom Bird sanctuary is an ornithologist's paradise. The main attractions here are local birds like the Cuckoo, Owl, Cormorant, Moorhen, Darter, Brahminy Kite and Duck. There are many migratory birds, like the Siberian Crane, that can be spotted here. Parrot, Teal, Lark, Flycatcher, etc. are also often sighted here. Some of Kumarakom's migratory birds come from the Himalayas, and a few from as far away as Siberia. On reaching Kumarakom, we check-in to our resort and have lunch. After lunch, we take a five-minute boat ride and walk a short distance to enter the bird sanctuary. Birdwatchers are in for a treat here! In the afternoons, you are likely to see large numbers of Herons and Egrets fly in to roost here. We stay in the Sanctuary until dusk, and we then return to the lodge for dinner.

We cruise in the backwaters of Kerala on a houseboat, locally known as ‘Kettuvalloms’. Located in the southwestern part of India, Kerala is one of the most beautiful parts of India. It is popularly known as ‘God’s Own Country’ because of its exquisite beauty and greenery. The houseboat takes us to Alappuzha (also called Allepey). Savor the beauty of the landscape as we drift along the narrow canals and paddy fields of the scenic backwaters.

At Alappuzha, we leave the houseboat in the morning after breakfast and we drive to Kochi (formerly known as Cochin). You have the day to yourself and can explore Kochi. Kochi is a pleasant market town surrounded by coconut plantations and built on the canals, which serve the area's coir industry. It is also one of India's principal seaports.
This is the last day of the tour. You can either explore the town or stay in at the hotel to relax till it is time to go to the airport to board your flight

tourName: Southern India wildlife holiday, tailor made
generalInfo:
South India is home to a dazzling range of rare and endemic species and we explore all of the individual forests, hillsides and waterways in search of some of the world's most charismatic and endangered species such as Asiatic elephants, Tigers, Hornbills and King Cobras.

Introduction:

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching tours and safari holidays all over the world, specialising in the Indian subcontinent and of course the wonderful and diverse country of India. Whilst most wildlife watchers who visit India spend time in the famous tiger reserves of the central plains or maybe the sub-Himalayan parks of the north west and north east. But these ecosystems and incredible wildlife are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the wildlife that India has to offer.

This tour explores some of the lesser known parks and takes you into the deepest parts of India’s southern rainforests and hillsides. All of this whilst escorted by our very own expert zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) coupled with local guides. Of course there is one species in particular that dominates everyone’s thoughts and dreams when they think of an Indian safari and that is the beautiful tiger.

Whilst there are chances of seeing tigers here we take time to showcase the tiger’s ecosystem in full and try and find as many other animals that share the forests with tigers. We also offer a few different ways of exploring the parks, so however you like to travel through the tiger’s habitat we have the tour for you, whether you want to drive around in your own jeep, walk through the forests and grasslands tracking the elusive big cat or even via a boat or canoe in the water ways of Periyar.

One of the reasons why our safaris of India are unique is that our background (as a company) is from a scientific and zoological standpoint and so have a great network of colleagues and contacts all over the world who are the people on the front line in search of the best new locations for wildlife watching in the wild. All of these reasons and many more make us experts in arranging and guiding safaris and are able to tailor a Indian safaris to any location to try to find them that you request. All you have to do is to get in touch with us and tell us your budget and your group size and where you would like to go on safari.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned vehicles with an excellent local driver for all transfers. We include internal flights where ever possible on all our Indian safaris. We use two brilliant full time guides; first a professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) will escort you on all your excursions and also a very knowledgeable English speaking local guide at each national park. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort is an expert in mammal biology, ecology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort has spent time studying and working with different species all over the world and he has years of experience guiding throughout most of India’s national parks. We also use local expert guides with decades of experience on all our Indian safaris. We also include all jeep safaris, guided walks, canoe safaris, boat-trips, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more individual safaris into national parks per tour than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the national parks to search for tigers and other wildlife. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on tigers and other Indian wildlife which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

March and April is the dry season and best for wildlife. For wildlife watching in southern India we recommend visiting during March and April (this is the best overall game viewing in the Indian Subcontinent’s main tiger reserves and national parks). This is towards the end of the hot dry season and offers the best chances of seeing wildlife as the hotter and drier it gets the more the wildlife aggregate around waterholes as well as there being less vegetation blocking the view.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our Indian safaris are guided by a zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) as well as local naturalist guides, drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife your watching.
• Our zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) that escorts all our Indian safaris has great experience guiding throughout India and the world, and specialising in big cat tracking and has worked with and tracked big cats on 4 continents.
• We use camera traps (where available) which will increase the chances of getting close up pictures and movies of tigers and other rare nocturnal wildlife.
• During this tour we explore various national parks and wildlife sanctuaries (Bandipur, Nagahole, Wayanad, Parambikulam, Eravikulam, Silent Valley and Periyar) which will give you a very good overview of the Western Ghats and Nilgiri biosphere wilderness.
• Travel to Silent Valley National Park for the rare and endemic lion-tailed macaques, that are best seen here than anywhere else in the world.
• By joining one of our Indian safaris you will have an overall wildlife experience as we are determined to showcase all of the wildlife of the parks we visit (not just tigers), you will not feel like a passenger in a rally and bounce all over the place in pursuit of tigers; we make sure all our Indian safaris are relaxed and environmentally friendly experiences. In fact the majority of tiger sightings that we enjoy in India are of tigers that our jeep and guides have found (as opposed to other operators who wait for a tiger to be seen and then stake out the waterhole surrounded by dozens of other jeeps), we always investigate any suspicious behaviour exhibited by their prey and usually find tigers by watching the deer and monkey behaviour as they change from relaxed to agitated when a predator is spotted.
• We have explored all the areas we visit in depth and have found the best and most conveniently located accommodations to stay in whilst searching out wildlife in isolated and remote places. Including some of the best and most ecologically friendly lodges in all of India.
• We are a member of Tour Operators for Tigers (TOFT) and we make sure that all of our tiger safaris run by their code of practice and we also make sure that all the accommodation we use is audited by TOFT to make sure of sustainable practices.
• All the above reasons give this our tiger tours and general wildlife holidays of India a great success rate of seeing tigers (100% in Bandhavgarh and close to 50% for this tour, which is very good considering the dense forests and vastness of the protected areas).
• We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout the India and are able to find and observe species that are difficult to find or overlooked sometimes such as Indian leopards, Asiatic elephants, water buffalo, sloth bears, jungle cats, dhole, gaur and hundreds other endangered, rare or endemic species throughout the tigers current distribution.
• Due to our greta network of guides and researchers throughout India we are able to organise tailor made safari to anywhere in India, whether it is Bandhavgarh, Kanha, Periyar, Kaziranga, Corbett, Ramthambore, Satpura, Tadoba, and many other wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari holiday to India.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour takes you to the southern states of Kerala and Karnataka and from the cities of Bangalore to Trivandrum, visiting Nagarhole, Bandipur, Parambikulam, Silent Valley & Eravikulam National Parks as well as Wayanad & Periyar Wildlife Sanctuaries.

Fitness Level:

The fitness level required for this safari holiday is not very high. The vast majority of the activities are conducted from vehicles so no fitness is required, but there is some walking involved. The walking is all done at a leisurely pace with regular breaks, anyone who is used to mild hiking will find this easy.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 18 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Bangalore / Bengaluru – Arrival – Once you arrive at the International Airport in Bangalore you will be met by your local Indian guide/driver. You will then be briefly transferred to he hotel for your first day in India and your evening meal. If you have arrived early enough there is the chance for some sightseeing of Bangalore; this is the technological hotspot of India and a city which is moving quickly into the 21st Century, as a result the contrast in modern and traditional India is a great mix to see. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Munnar & Eravikulam National Park – Travelling & Wildlife Watching – Day 10 is dependant on where we are on day 9. If we stayed in Parambikulam National Park we will rise early and head out on a walk which will focus on some of the endemic birds such as grey jungle fowl, white-bellied blue flycatchers and white-bellied treepies; before breakfast and being transferred to Munnar (~4.5 hours). If we have been in Palakkad we will have a leisurely breakfast before being transferred to Munnar (~6 hours). After arriving in Munnar you will have the rest of the day at your leisure or enjoy a sort sightseeing trip around Munnar. On day 11 you will go hiking in Eravikulam National Park. This national park is home to the highly endangered and endemic Nilgiri tahr. This rare highland goat can only be seen here and we have a good chance of spotting some today. The birding is also exceptional here and we will try and find some of the key species such as yellow-throated bulbuls, blue-faced molkohas, Nilgiri pipits, Nilgiri pigeons and black and orange flycatchers. Some other mammals that can be found here are short-claws otters, Nilgiri martens, dusky-striped squirrels and ruddy mongooses, although hard to see we will keep our eyes peeled. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Periyar Wildlife Sanctuary – Travelling & Wildlife Watching – This morning you will be transferred to your last wildlife watching destination which is Periyar Wildlife Sanctuary after breakfast (~4 hours). Periyar Wildlife Sanctuary is one of the largest and most famous protected areas in all of southern India. Periyar is full of water ways and lakes and is nestled in the middle of spice and rubber plantations and provides a great home for a vast array of animal life; including 62 species of mammal, 320 species of birds, 45 species of reptiles, 27 species of amphibians and 38 species of fish! Our aim is to try and find some of these specific animals here over the next couple of days. On arrival at the lodge and after checking in you will be taken to the sanctuary for a short boat ride on Periyar lake. On the lake we will hopefully find short-clawed otters, black bazas, woolly-necked storks and possibly the two freshwater turtle species that live here. Then on day 13 you will start with a short jeep safari in the national park before breakfast, followed by a 4 hour guided walk through the sanctuary before a 2 hour long boat trip after lunch. Or you have the option for a full day jeep safari inside Periyar. Either way we will search for some of the 1,000 Asiatic elephants, guar, Indian muntjac, Nilgiri tahr, tigers, leopards and dhole. If you are out all day you will take a packed lunch with you otherwise you will return to the lodge for meals between safari activities. Then on day 14 you will be taken on a guided walk in the morning. During this time we will focus on the very rare, smaller animals such as Malabar giant squirrels, lion-tailed macaques, Nilgiri langurs, side-striped mongooses, Nilgiri martens, blue-winged parakeets, rufous babblers, broad-tailed grass warblers and king cobras (the largest and most impressive venomous snake in the world). Then in the afternoon you will have the rest of the day to relax or possibly enjoy a spice plantation tour. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Trivandrum – Travelling – Today you will be taken to the coastal city of Trivandrum in our private vehicle where you will have a night on the coast before returning to Bangalore tomorrow. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Bangalore – Travelling – Today you will be taken to the airport in time to catch your return flight back to Bangalore, then after arriving back at the accommodation. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).
Home – Departure – This morning after breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (Breakfast only).

tourName: Tadoba National park tiger safari, India
placesVisited: Tadoba National Park, 8 tiger safaris, Luxurious safari lodge accommodation
generalInfo:
This eight day tiger safari takes place in one location, Tadoba National Park, giving plenty of time to really feel immersed in this well known tiger habitat. After taking a flight from Delhi to Nagpur, and then a two hour transfer by car or minibus, you arrive at this wonderfully remote park that is well off the normal tourist tiger trail. The name of this tiger watching terrain comes from the indigenous tribe’s language, as Tadoba was a deity worshipped by them. Indeed, the indigenous people still live in this region and, having been stewards of it for generations. It is fitting, therefore, that this responsible tiger watching holiday ensures that it supports local conservation initiatives, as well as the economy. Many of the indigenous people are now being trained as naturalists and will, therefore, guide you on your safaris, morning and night, through this special park, also their ancestral home.

Tadoba National Park’s tiger population is thriving and, for that reason, it is believed to be one of the best places to see tiger in the country. We also offer one of the best lodges that you will find on a tiger safari holiday surrounded by forest and watering holes, making this an ideal location for you not only to relax after safari, but also watch out for other wildlife, including prolific birdlife, take photographs as the sun sets, or simply sit back and enjoy the lodge’s fine Indian food and hospitality.
Note: Pench Tiger Reserve or Kanha National park extension is available.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi,our executive will meet you at the Airport, transfer to Hotel. Overnight Hotel on B&B

Take a direct flight to Nagpur,departs at 07:30 Hrs reaches Nagpur at 09:15 hrs,drive to tadoba (2hrs drive) today we relax overnight lodge The Project Tiger Reserve encompasses Tadoba National Park & Andhari River Wildlife Sanctuary. The river is a vital life support system. The Southern tropical dry deciduous forests are home to tigers, leopard, wild dog, deer, sloth bear and bison apart from diverse wilderness. The mugger crocodile is also found here. The wildlife reserve has become popular for tiger safari because of frequent sightings of tigers in their natural habitat. You will be able to see and photograph the big cats on your tour with ease. As wildlife tour specialists we will leave no stone unturned to make your safaris as exciting as it could. It will be a journey of discovery and a photographic expedition that would yield amazing results.
Morning & evening safari at Tadoba National Park
Morning & evening safari at Tadoba National Park
Morning & evening safari at Tadoba National Park
Morning & evening safari at Tadoba National Park
Drive back to Nagpur (Lunch at Nagpur) to connect direct flight to New delhi,departs at 18:05 reaches Delhi at 19:40 overnight Delhi
Transfer to international airport. Note: Extension to Kanha National park is available on request.

tourName: Tiger and Kerala beaches tour in India
generalInfo:
This holiday is a blend of wildlife adventure in central India with a relaxing holiday on the backwaters of Kerala in south India. Bandhavgarh, Kanha and Pench are the three best national parks in the world to see wild tigers and other animals.

Bandhavgarh, infused with history and highest density of tigers in the world. Kanha with its moist deciduous forest has rich biodiversity of mammals and birds. Pench is the original setting of The Jungle book with thriving tiger and wild dog population.

Next leg of your journey will take you to Kerala where you will visit the mountains of Munnar to see spice gardens and tea plantations. Move next to inland waterways of Alleppy to experience a night in house boat as you paddle along the backwaters. Finally enjoy warm tropical beaches of Kovalam on the Arabian sea.

dayInfo.description: NEW DELHI – JABALPUR – BANDHAVGARH TIGER RESERVE. Your tour will start in Delhi airport from here you will catch flight to Jabalpur in central India. Jabalpur is the closest airport to the Bandhavgarh tiger reserve. Morning 10:10 am Spice Jet direct flight will take you into the heart of India. In flight meals will be provided to you so you can continue straight to Bandhavgarh from the airport. You will reach Jabalpur at 12:05 pm where you will be met by your driver and taken on 4 hours drive to Bandhavgarh. Your car will be stocked with water, juice, cookies and fresh fruits in case if you feel hungry. The route is busy initially with traffic but soon you rural India will take over and you will pass through several big and small villages which provide fantastic photo opportunity. Check-in to your lodge which is nestled comfortably in the lap of nature just on the edge of Bandhavgarh. Boundary of the park runs right in front of the lodge and often in evening and early morning you hear alarm cries of deer alerting guests of the leopard patrolling its territory. Relax at the camp with some refreshing drinks. Dinner is usually served at 07:30 pm but if you want to retire early, you can ask the staff to accommodate your request of early supper. Meals: D

BANDHAVGARH TIGER RESERVE. The day starts early in Bandhavgarh. You will be given wake-up call with tea/coffee and biscuits to awaken your senses. Head out into the jungle in an open 4x4 jeep in search of world’s most elusive cat - tiger and other wildlife of Bandhavgarh. Breakfast will be carried along that you can enjoy in the designated spots in the reserve. The reserve is named after the highest hill Bandhavgarh (807 m.) in the centre of the Reserve. Wildlife includes the spotted deer or chital, chinkara,?chousingha or four-horned antelope, wild boar,?sambhar, muntjac and nilgai. Each outing in the?reserve provides a chance to meet one of its rarer inhabitants such as sloth bear, Indian fox, jackal,?wolf and jungle cat. Other animals?present in larger numbers in the reserve include?3 species of mongoose, rhesus macaque,?Indian hare and the delightful palm squirrel.?Common Langurs are also plentiful. 242 species of?birds have been identified in the reserve. The most?commonly seen are the peafowl, red jungle fowl,?grey hornbill, red-wattled lapwing, crested serpent eagle, white-breasted kingfisher and lesser adjutant stork. Plainly, the biggest draw of the park is the unparalleled opportunity it offers to observe and photograph tiger behaviour for sustained periods of time. Tracking the known individuals by territory and movement, the extraordinarily skilled guides and drivers yield intimate photo opportunities and unique insights into the public life of the enigmatic big cat. After morning safari you will come back to the lodge between 10:00 – 11:00 am when the park closes for few hours before opening up again in late afternoon. You will go out again in evening safari around 03:30 pm to try your luck with the wild cats and other wildlife of Bandhavgarh. Besides safari you can go for a picnic, walk or cycle on the periphery of the park. Periphery also known as buffer are is full of life. Many villages dot the area that were relocated from inside the park. Buffer is aimed at promoting co-existence between wildlife and human activity. You can see many species of birds, meet the villagers and if luck favours, you can also catch a glimpse of chinkara antelope along with other wildlife. You will get to see and learn more while you are on foot or bicycle with a guide from a village. You can also simply stay back at your camp and lie on the veranda with a book from a library Spend two more nights here in search of tiger and other wildlife in morning and evening jeep safari with the last day free to relax. Meals: B L D

BANDHAVGARH – KANHA TIGER RESERVE. After breakfast leave Bandhavgarh and travel south to Kanha Tiger Reserve (270 km). A drive of six hours will take you through the scenic rural environs of Central India. You will reach Kanha around lunch time. Your accommodation will be luxurious tented camp on the quieter Mukki side of the park. The tents are canvas–walled homes on solid foundations with ensuite bathrooms. This eco lodge proudly employs local. At the centre of camp is a water reserve charged all year round by two natural springs, which attracts an array of birds including kingfishers, cormorants and the seasonal breeding of hundreds of egrets. Relax at the camp or go for birding around the camp in evening. Meals: B L D

KANHA TIGER RESERVE. A typical day as in most of the reserves, start early with tea/coffee before you explore the jungle on the morning safari. Picnic breakfast is carried along to enjoy it under the forest canopy of the reserve. Return back by late morning to dust off and rest before you set out again on the evening safari to try your luck with further wildlife spotting. Kanha National Park, located in the Maikal hills of the Satpura mountain ranges, famed for its beautiful meadows is home to 22 species of large mammals including a number of tigers and well over 250 species of birds. Kanha is also the home to the highly endangered barasingha deer. The hard- ground race of this deer is endemic to Kanha. Commonly spotted animals include sambar, the largest of the Indian deer, spotted deer, barking deer, wild boar and jackal. One can also see the sloth bear, leopard, wild dogs, as well as the thickly muscled gaur or Indian bison. The habitat type of Kanha comprises of grasslands, pure Sal, bamboo and mixed forest zones with small rivulets and wetlands. The diverse habitat support birds including the racket-tailed drongo, 5 species of doves, flycatchers, Malabar pied hornbill, lesser whistling duck, common teal, pintail, cotton pygmy goose, woolly-necked and black stork, hoopoe and the shoveler. Crested serpent eagle, honey buzzard, shikra and the black-winged kite are the main birds of prey. In a region as this the presence of water attracts wildlife. Luckily, the Tiger Reserve contains pools and streams, which ensure that it is frequented by both game and predators. Explore the Tiger Reserve mainly by following a network of jeep tracks that will lead you into the forested areas. ?Along with safaris, you can also choose to go on a walk on Wednesday evening since the park is closed. Walks are conducted in the buffer area of the reserve providing ample opportunities to see birds, butterflies and occasional bison, deer and also leopard. Kanha has also been home to many forest dwelling tribes. Villages or tola of Baiga tribes are dotted all around the reserve. You can take a break from a daily drives and visit Baiga village and meet the locals that will give you an insight how people once co-existed in harmony with nature. You can also visit tribal weekly markets The markets are an opportunity for all communities to come together to bargain or barter for their weekly stores. Explore Kanha for two full days. Meals: B L D

KANHA – PENCH TIGER RESERVE After morning safari travel west to Pench Tiger Reserve (150 km/3 hours) the forest which inspired Rudyard Kipling. On route you will see some Indian birds, typically black kites, laughing and spotted doves, rose-ringed parakeets, little swifts, little green bee -eaters, black drongos, and a variety of shrikes, mynas, bulbuls and babblers. Arrive Pench in evening and check into a jungle camp to relax amidst its natural setting. It is well placed in the buffer zone of the park. Ethnically designed in keeping with the native culture, the camp showcases a pastoral jungle theme making it a unique holiday getaway. Meals: B L D

PENCH TIGER RESERVE Named after the Pench river, the reserve is located in the southern reaches of the Satpura hill range, a total of 758 sq. kms of this southern Indian tropical moist deciduous forest is dominated by teak trees. The Pench reservoir at the center of the Reserve is the only major water source during pinch period. In winter the same reservoir attracts huge number of waders to its banks. Pench has good numbers of oriole, both black-hooded and golden, along with high density of raptors. The most common and frequently sighted raptor includes, short-toed snake eagle and crested serpent eagle with the occasional sighting of booted and tawny eagle. Pench also has some the highest deer/ antelope density in India attracting good numbers of carnivore species. Major ungulate species consists of Spotted Deer, sambhar, nilgai and barking deer along with world’s biggest wild cattle; gaur or the Indian bison. The apex species in the food chain includes tiger, leopard, wild dogs and occasionally seen Indian wolf. Altogether, Pench is home to 39 species of mammals, 13 species of reptiles, 3 species of amphibians and over 190 varieties of birds have already been listed. Spend an adventure filled day here with morning and evening game drives in search of birds and the elusive tiger or just by relaxing and watching your lodge’s local wildlife. Meals: B L D

PENCH – NAGPUR – MUMBAI – COCHIN Today is a long day ahead. Start early from Pench and drive to Nagpur airport (2 hrs) to catch flight to Mumbai. At Mumbai you will need to change the flight and board the flight to Cochin in Kerala. You will reach Cochin in evening and will be met by your driver who will take you to the hotel for a night stay. You can extend your stay in Cochin by one day and visit local attraction. You can visit Mattancherry Palace, Kerala Folklore Museum. Some other attractions include Pardesi Synagogue, Santa Cru Basilica and Maritime Museum. You can have a leisurely walk on the beach in the evening and will return back to the hotel for dinner and overnight stay. Meals: B

COCHIN – MUNNAR Today after breakfast drive to the beautiful hill station of Munnar (4 hrs). Munnar is 1800 mts above sea level and also the place of South India’s highest peak (Anamudi - 2695 mts). On arrival at Munnar transfer to Hotel. Check in at Hotel. There are plenty of things to do in Munnar. You can visit Rajamala (Eravikulam National Park - open as per the directions by the forest authorities ), the best place to see Nilgiri Tahr (Hermitragus Hilarious) - the mountain goat of South India. Filled with Tea Plantations, Munnar presents greenery at its best. You can visit Tata Tea Factory where you can see the entire process of tea making. In evening you visit Thirumeny Cultural Centre. Here you can enjoy Indian Kathakali show and Indian Martial Arts – Kalari! After this enjoy the scenic beauty of Attukal Waterfalls. In the evening, we shall return back to the hotel for dinner and night stay. Meal: B
MUNNAR Explore more of Munnar’s natural beauty today with plenty of waterfalls, hills and forest. Meals: B

MUNNAR – ALLEPPEY You next destination is Alleppey which is about 4.5 hours drive from Munnar. Start your journey after breakfast. Allepey is a laid down small town of South India yet staying here is different experience. Houseboats are an enduring experience here. These man- made living houses on the river have everything to make you get a different experience. Enjoy the scenic beauty of the riverside, coconut palms, Chinese Fishing Nets, children playing, all while you sit in the boat sipping hot filter coffee and savouring south Indian delicacies. If you wish you can also enjoy Kayaking through narrow backwater canals and Ayurvedic messages. Night stay and dinner in the houseboat which is equipped with comfortable bedroom and a proper bathroom. Meals: B L D

ALLEPPY – KOVALAM After having relishing breakfast, the boat will bring you back to the dock around 10:00 am to meet your driver who will take you to the beach town of Kovalam (4.5 hrs) Accommodation here will be a beach resort. Kovalam is an evergreen and pleasant climatic beach resort. Kovalam is a dreamland for tourists all over the world. The warm and clean atmosphere by the coconut trees and the white sandbed are perfect for relaxing holidays, as the sea breeze gently plays with the waves. Relax at the hotel or lay on the beach. Meals: B

KOVALAM The leisure options at this beach are plenty and diverse. Sunbathing, swimming, herbal body toning massages, special cultural programmes and catamaran cruising are some of them. The tropical sun acts so fast that one can see the faint blush of coppery tan on the skin in a matter of minutes. Life on the beach begins late in the day and carries on well into the night. The beach complex includes a string of hotels, shopping zones, Yoga and Ayurvedic massage centres. Trivandrum or Thiruvananthapuram, the capital city of Kerala, is just 16 km away. The city of has many interesting places to see like the Napier Museum, the Sri Chitra Art Gallery and the Padmanabhaswamy Temple. The SMSM Institute, a State owned handicrafts emporium, is the ideal place to pick up ethnic curios and other articles. Relax in Kovalam for 3 full days. Meals: B
KOVALAM – TRIVANDRUM – NEW DELHI Today you will be transferred to Trivandrum airport to catch flight to New Delhi for your onward journey. Meals: B

tourName: Tiger and wildlife photography tour, India
generalInfo:
Embark on an unforgettable photo safari tour through Central India's captivating wildlife. This thoughtfully crafted itinerary takes you to three renowned national parks, offering an exceptional opportunity to see and photograph the magnificent royal Bengal tiger and an array of fascinating creatures that call this region home.

Your journey commences at Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve, where history merges with the world's highest density of tigers. Prepare for thrilling tiger sightings as you delve deeper into the reserve, alongside encounters with the jungle cat, ruddy mongoose, and mighty gaur.

Next, travel to the captivating landscapes of Kanha Tiger Reserve, known for its biodiversity and picturesque meadows within Sal forests. Spot tigers and the unique barasingha deer, as Kanha's pristine beauty and thriving wildlife leave you in awe of nature's wonders.

Concluding the tour is Pench, the inspirational setting of Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book. Its dry deciduous forests host a thriving population of tigers, leopards, and wild dogs, sustained by the abundant herbivores. Prepare for extraordinary wildlife encounters as you traverse this magical terrain.

Twice-daily safaris in open 4x4s, guided by experienced local trekkers and English-speaking guides, ensure expert knowledge and insights. Their familiarity with individual tigers and their territories enhances your chances of remarkable sightings and fantastic photo opportunities.

Your comfort is paramount, with accommodations ranging from well-appointed mid-range lodges to luxurious safari tents. Each offers a tranquil retreat amidst nature's splendour, coupled with delightful culinary experiences featuring a blend of Indian and Western cuisine.

tourName: Tiger safari and Golden Triangle tour in India
placesVisited: Guided tour of Old Delhi, Jama Masjid mosque, Agra, Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Itmad-ud-daulah, game drives in Ranthambhore, Jaipur, Delhi
generalInfo:
Explore the ancient land of India and discover a country that's blessed in a rich variety of culture, heritage and wildlife. For first-timers, the Golden Triangle and Tiger Safari offers a fantastic introduction to the diverse country and really encapsulates the essence of India.

This 11-day tour starts in the history-rich capital of Delhi. Explore the cities hidden corners, bustling bazaars and local specialities. From here travel by rail to Agra to see the majestic Taj Mahal at sunrise. Your journey then takes you into the colourful state of Rajasthan, visiting Ranthambhore National Park for its impressive fort and abundant wildlife. From here your adventure will continue onto the pink city of Jaipur where you can visit the beautiful Amber Palace.

dayInfo.description: Depart the UK on a direct flight from London to Delhi. Overnight on flight.

You will be met on arrival at Delhi International Airport and will be taken to your hotel. In the afternoon you will have a guided tour of Old Delhi including a visit to Jama Masjid mosque and a cycle rickshaw ride through the bustling bazaar area.

Explore the contrasts of Old and New Delhi on a private guided tour. This includes the enormous Jama Masjid from which you can walk through the bazaars and narrow streets - a great way to absorb the sights and sounds of Old Delhi. See the monumental buildings set along wide boulevards of Lutyens' New Delhi, including India Gate and the President's residence.

This morning you will be taken to the railway station where you will take the train to Agra. In the afternoon, take a private guided walk around Agra's sights, such as the impressive Moghul Red Fort. The Red Fort is a great preview to visiting the Taj Mahal in the morning - the two were built during the same period and have much shared history.

Visit the magnificent Taj Mahal at sunrise this morning, the quietest and most tranquil time to visit, before the crowds arrive. In the afternoon you will be taken to the station to catch your train to Sawai Madhopur, the station that serves Ranthambhore National Park.

Morning and afternoon game drives in Ranthambhore are included today. This world-famous national park was once the private hunting ground of the Maharaja of Jaipur. Today the park is well-visited due to its high number of tiger sightings in the jungle, and at natural and man-made pools.
Rise early for your last morning game drive in Ranthambhore. In the afternoon you will drive on to the Pink City of Jaipur which will take approximately four hours.
Spend the day exploring Jaipur's sights. Visit the Palace of the Winds, the Jantar Mantar Observatory and the impressive Amber Fort just outside of the city.

Morning at leisure to relax at your hotel. In the afternoon you will head out on a tour of Jaipur's bustling bazaars, offering the opportunity to get behind the scenes of local markets with the chance to meet local traders and artisans.
Today you will be driven back to Delhi. The journey takes approximately five to six hours. Rest of the day at leisure.
Transfer to the airport for your flight home.

tourName: Tiger tour in India, land of the Tiger tour
placesVisited: Pench National Park, Kanha National Park, Bandhavgarh National Park, Sleeper train to Agra, Taj Mahal, Delhi
generalInfo:
Tiger tours in India offer an amazing opportunity to get up close to one of the world’s most endearing, yet deadly, predators, which is why this tour has been designed to make the most of Northern India’s premier national parks in order to increase chances of safety and success.

The protected areas of Bandhavgarh, Pench and Kanha national parks make ideal destinations for tiger tours in India with an abundance of alternative animal action adding to excitement levels as you go exploring on 15 individual India tiger tours over the course of two weeks.

Early booking recommendation:

Due to recent changes in the management of India tiger tours, and organising game drives in general, it’s now imperative to book wildlife safaris well in advance. A full list of traveller names and personal information details will be required to book your place on an India game drive with a no refund and a no name change policy also added to recent updates by the Indian authorities. In light of these changes we recommend all of our India tiger tours should be confirmed at least six months in advance which allows us, as tour operators, to work within the new guidelines and ensure game drives are secured for you, the client. Please note: it’s also imperative that guidelines are read and understood prior to booking. Thank you.

dayInfo.description: Our adventure begins in Delhi, a colourful and chaotic city full of architectural masterpieces. Around 6pm, say namaste to your tour leader and fellow travellers, when we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Your tour leader then ensures a big welcome by arranging a group dinner at a nearby restaurant. Want more time in Delhi? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Accommodation: Indus Biznotel (or similar)

The group will transfer to Delhi Domestic Airport for a flight (around 1hr 40min) to Nagpur. The drive to Pench National Park, where your safari adventures begin, will take approximately three hours. Accommodation: Pench Jungle Camp (or similar)

Spend two days exploring Pench National Park in the lower southern reaches of the Satpuda hills. It provided inspiration for Rudyard Kipling's The Jungle Book and marks our first chance to see our very own Shere Khan. This designated tiger reserve is home to around 45 Bengal tigers, plus leopards, wolves, monkeys, deer, and nilgai (the largest antelope in Asia). Our two days include four game drives, in which we’ll keep our eyes peeled for the incredible creatures that live here. Accommodation: Pench Jungle Camp (or similar)

We depart in the morning and drive to Kanha National Park. Although the distance is not far, the journey usually takes approximately four hours. On arrival, there is time to relax by the pool and share wildlife stories with your fellow travellers. Accommodation: Celebration Van Vilas (or similar)

Created in 1974, Kanha National Park is often described as the greatest wildlife reserve in India – during our time here, we go on five game drives to explore it. The park is vast, encompassing expansive grasslands, plateaus and dramatic rocky escarpments that house hundreds of wildlife species. The tiger population – which currently numbers around 500 – has been affected by poaching in recent years but the huge abundance of animals makes the game drives a memorable experience. Accommodation: Celebration Van Vilas (or similar)

We leave Kanha National Park after breakfast and drive to Bandhavgarh, stopping en route for refreshments. This journey will take approximately six to seven hours. On arrival there is free time to settle in. Accommodation: Nature Heritage Resort (or similar)

Bandhavgarh is one of the smaller national parks and enjoys an impressive setting with a cliff-top fort overlooking grasslands, birch forests and bamboo. It is home to a wide variety of game, including leopards, sloth bears, jungle cats, wild pigs and, of course, tigers. The healthy tiger population of approximately 60-70 means this park has the highest tiger density of any reserve in India. The park also hosts up to 150 bird species including many on the migratory trail, such as the steppe eagle. During our stay, we embark on six games drives. Accommodation: Nature Heritage Resort (or similar)

This morning, we drive for approximately three hours to Katni Railway Station. We stop for refreshments, conveniences and photo opportunities along the way. In the evening, we catch the overnight train to Agra. Accommodation: Overnight sleeper train

Arriving in Agra in the morning, we transfer to our hotel. No stay in Agra would be complete without a visit to the Taj Mahal, built by the Moghul emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife, Mumtaz Mahal, who died in 1631. The Taj is serenely beautiful and never fails to amaze a first-time visitor – the white marble exterior changing colour according to the position of the sun. Nearby is the imposing Red Fort of Akbar, whose mighty sandstone walls enclose the beautiful white marble Pearl Mosque, palaces, halls, courtyards and fountains. Please note: In December and January, our Taj Mahal visit is earlier in the afternoon to avoid fog that can limit visibility during sunset. Accommodation: Howard Plaza The Fern (or similar)

After breakfast, we begin our journey (approximately four to five hours) back to Delhi, stopping on the outskirts of Agra to visit and support Wildlife SOS. Their work is dedicated to rescuing and caring for sloth bears and elephants. At the Agra Elephant Conservation and Care Centre, we meet an education officer to learn about their vital work and commitment to rehabilitating abused elephants and advocating for their conservation through public awareness campaigns. We take a tour and see some of the rescued elephants and hear their stories. After this informative visit, we resume our drive to Delhi and check into our hotel. It’s your last night together so the tour leader can help to arrange a group dinner Accommodation: Hotel Deventure (or similar)
Our adventure draws to a close after breakfast. If you’d like a little more time in Delhi, speak to your sales representative about extending your stay.

tourName: Tiger watching holiday in India
placesVisited: Delhi, Kanha National Park, Bandhavgarh National Park, Sleeper train journey from Delhi, Jabalpur, Trained naturalist guides from local community, 10 game drives
generalInfo:
The itinerary for this nine day tiger watching holiday with Indian wildlife experts has been crafted in a way that makes the most of every opportunity possible to see not only the magnificent tigers of Madhya Pradesh state and, in particular Kanha National Park and Bandhavgarh National Park, but also a plethora of other wildlife. Plus the guides on this trip are all expert naturalists from the region, who will share all their knowledge and passion for conservation while on the tiger safari with you.

After a sleeper train journey from Delhi, your first safari experience is in Bandhavgarh National Park, celebrated as the place where the rare white tigers were captured for the Maharaja of Rewa, the last one thought to have been seized in the mid 1990’s. Today it is an extraordinary arid landscape, where a 2000 year old ruined fort provides dramatic rocky terrain, surrounded by caves and chasms for tiger to roam. As well as the park’s other wild residents, with mammals and reptiles ranging from monkeys to mongoose, leopard to lizards, snakes to sambar. As well as 138 species of resident birds, and flocks of many other migratory ones passing through too. Kanha National Park proffers an eclectic mix of habitats over its almost 2000 sq. km of grassy plateaus, open plains and resplendent Shorea robusta or sal forests. All perfect terrain for tiger as well as the endangered and exquisite Barasingha Deer.

A large part of Kanha National Park also falls into the domain of Kanha Tiger Reserve, an important conservation initiative from the 1970’s led by Project Tiger. Kanha is also famous for being the first place where leading biologist and conservationist, George Shaller, carried out the first scientific research into tigers in the 1960’s. Today there are approximately one hundred tiger here, as well as leopard, wild dogs, langur monkeys, chital, sambhar and mongoose. This tiger watching holiday includes jungle accommodation, all meals, safaris and expert naturalist guide.

Note: An extension to see Taj Mahal at Agra is available.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi & transfer to hotel. Local sightseeing arranged on request if time permits. Overnight hotel.
Overnight sleeper train to Umariya.

Reach Umariya early morning. Drive to Bandhavgarh National Park (34 km) in AC car/coach. Evening game drive. Overnight lodge. Hidden in the remote confines of Madhya Pradesh or Central India the historic assemblage of caves, fort, idols and temples accentuate its appeal fourfold. Tigers prefer to hunt in the marshy grasslands inundated by rivulets the life line of this charming ecosystem. A journey in the hinterlands of India is always rewarding especially if the targeted species is the majestic Bengal tiger.
Bandhavgarh NP. Morning & evening game drives. Overnight lodge.
Transfer early morning to Kanha NP. Reach Kanha by lunch time. Evening game drive. Overnight lodge.
Kanha NP. Morning & evening game drives. Overnight lodge.
Transfer to Jabalpur. Today after breakfast we drive back to Jabalpur for lunch. Later we board a direct overnight train to New Delhi, packed dinner onboard.
Arrive Delhi transfer to Hotel.Overnight Hotel.
Transfer to International airport. Note: Extension available for Agra to see Taj Mahal or full Golden Triangle.

tourName: Tiger & wildlife tour in Central India
placesVisited: Game drives in Bandhavgarh and Pench tiger reserves, mongoose, Rhesus macaques, Indian hares and Palm squirrels, Kanha tiger reserve, Optional tour extensions to Agra and Satpura tiger reserve
generalInfo:
If you're hankering for a spot of excitement and you've always fancied the thought of a tiger safari, India is fast-becoming one of the world's most important countries to spot these noble creatures within their natural environment.

Of course, tiger safaris in India don't just focus upon tracking these big cats at the cost of all else. There's a huge range of wildlife within India's protected nature reserves with wild dogs, leopards, swamp deer and a vast array of indigenous and visiting bird species adding to the obvious adventure of spotting a tiger stalking through the undergrowth.

Overnight accommodation on this ten day India tiger safari adheres to strict environmental practices with local people also benefiting from responsible travellers just as much as the natural habitat that surrounds the comfortable and well-equipped safari camps.

Below are a few more highlights which make this tiger safari India stand out from the crowd:

- Experience twelve wildlife safari tours by open-top four-by-four Jeep.
- Look for wild animals in their natural habitat as you stay within the tiger reserves of Bandhavgarh, Kanha and Pench.
- Benefit from the knowledge and expertise of trained tour leaders and local wildlife guides.

dayInfo.description: New Delhi-Bandhavgarh: Your tour will start at Delhi airport. From here, you will catch a flight to Jabalpur in central India. Your driver will meet you at Jabalpur Airport and transfer you to Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve. The drive of 4.5 hours will take you through the scenic rural environs of central India. Reach Bandhavgarh in the evening and check check-in at your jungle lodge which is nestled comfortably on the edge of the reserve and often in the evening and early morning you hear alarm cries of deer alerting guests of the leopard patrolling its territory. The evening is free to relax at the camp with some refreshing drinks. Retire early to explore Bandhavgarh early the next morning.

Bandhavgarh: The Reserve is named after the highest hill Bandhavgarh (807 m.) in the centre of the Reserve. Bandhavgarh has the highest density of tiger population in the country and hence offers the best chance to see them in the wild. The Spotted Deer, or Chital, is a favourite item on the Tiger menu and several thousand of these delightful deer inhabit the Reserve. Other species found here in varying abundance include chinkara, wild boar, sambar deer, barking deer and blue bull. Each outing in the Reserve provides a chance to meet one of its rarer inhabitants such as a sloth bear, Bengal fox, jackal and jungle cat. Other animals present in more significant numbers in the Reserve include the ruddy mongoose, rhesus macaque, Indian hare and the delightful palm squirrel. Common langurs are also plentiful, sitting with an elevated view of the forest as they devour their favourite leaves. Explore Bandhavgarh for another 2 days with four safaris and jungle walks.

Bandhvgarh-Kanha: After breakfast drive south to Kanha tiger reserve. A drive through rural central India will take you to the southern entrance of the reserve comparably less touristy to the northern side. For the journey, packed lunch will be carried along which will be enjoyed in any of the several villages you will be passing through. Check into the luxury tented camp which is located at the peaceful entry point of the reserve. The tents are canvas-walled homes on solid foundations with ensuite bathrooms. Upon reaching Kanha relax at the camp or go for a walk looking for resident wildlife which includes various species of butterflies and birds.

Kanha: Before the crack of dawn you will be given a wake-up call with tea/coffee to wake your senses. Set on a game drive on 4x4 in search of the world's most elusive cat. Kanha National Park is located in the Maikal hills of the Satpura mountain ranges. Sal tree predominates the area with a mixed forest of bamboo and teak. Meadows dot the park serving excellent grazing grounds for numerous prey species. Wildlife is abundant here with tigers at the top of the food chain. The park is home to 22 species of large mammals and well over 200 species of birds. Commonly spotted animals include the sambar, the largest of the Indian deer, nilgai or blue bull and the barking deer. One can also see the sloth bear, locally called Bhaloo, the same name given by Rudyard Kipling to the loveable bear in "Jungle Book" as well as the thickly muscled gaur or Indian bison. Explore Kanha in four morning and afternoon safaris along with walks in the buffer forest. There is also an option of going on a night drive to experience the jungle at night and to see nocturnal wildlife.

Kanha-Pench: After an easy morning leave for Pench tiger reserve in the west. A 4-hour drive will take you to the forest which inspired Rudyard Kipling. Your accommodation here will be a beautiful camp located between a village Pench tiger reserve. Settle in your camp to explore Pench tomorrow.

Pench: Today explore Pench in morning and afternoon safari. Named after the Pench River, the reserve is located in the southern reaches of the Satpura hill range, a total of 758 sq. km of this Southern Indian tropical moist deciduous forest is dominated by teak trees. Pench also has some of the highest deer/antelope densities in India, attracting good numbers of carnivore species. Major ungulate species include spotted deer, sambhar, nilgai and barking deer along with the world's biggest wild cattle, the gaur or Indian bison. The apex species in the food chain include tiger, leopard, Asiatic wild dogs and the rarely seen Indian wolf. Altogether, Pench is home to 39 species of mammals, 13 species of reptiles, 3 species of amphibians and over 200 species of birds have already been listed.
Pench-Nagpur-New Delhi: Today after breakfast drive to Nagpur city (2 hours) to catch a flight back to New Delhi.

tourName: Tigers and rhinos tours in India
placesVisited: Delhi, Sonakhali, Sunderbans UNESCO World Heritage Site, Kaziranga National Park, Three game safaris, Calcutta, Island of Bali, River cruise
generalInfo:
This tour is a unique combination of India’s wildlife. We will be visiting Sunderbans, a UNESCO World Heritage Site to see its famous swimming tigers, as well as Kaziranga National Park for rhinos. Your first stop is Kaziranga NP, one of the world’s beacons of conservation, having successfully protected its great one horned rhinos, and now home to two thirds of the world’s population of them. With over 2,400 of them today in the park, rhino safaris here are second to none. The park is also a tiger reserve and, as if that isn’t enough, other animals that you will be able to look out for on your morning and evening game safaris here include elephants, water buffalo and superb birdlife.

In contrast, your time spent in the Sunderbans, in the state of West Bengal and accessed by an internal flight to Calcutta and onward transfer to Sonakhali, is all about water. This UNESCO World Heritage Site recognises the importance of this vast wetland of estuarine forests, mangroves and maze of rivers around the Ganga delta. On two different river cruises you will have chances to spot creatures ranging from crocodiles to chitals, wild boar to Olive Ridley turtles. The birdlife is sublime too, with kingfishers, ibis, herons and storks dipping and diving all around and, last but not least, this is home to the largest population of Bengal tigers.

A tailor made itinerary to suit your interests, many of our guests often add on Kanha National Park to the trip, another haven for tigers. Or else, for a cultural highlight, we can organise a trip to Agra to see the Taj Mahal.

We recommend the best time to go wildlife watching for tigers and rhinos is between October and April.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi at 2330 hrs. You will be met and transferred to the hotel for overnight stay on B&B.

Fly to Guwahati in the morning and transfer to Kaziranga National Park (4½ hr). In the evening tribal or Bihu dance (subject to availability) by log fire under bamboo grove along with dinner. Overnight at Wildlife Resort.
Game safari. Morning & evening game safari
Morning & evening game safari
Drive to Guwahati to connect flight to Calcutta. Arrive in Calcutta in the Evening. Overnight stay at Hotel.

River cruise. You are met in the morning and transferred by a comfortable vehicle to the jetty at Sonakhali. The 2½ hour drive takes through the lush-green rural Bengal landscape, dotted with its picturesque villages and quaint markets. Our personal boat, the M.B. Sundari awaits you here. You cruise down the rivers Hogol, Gomor, Durgaduani, Bidya and the Gumdi. As you sip tea or coffee, our resident naturalist explains the many mysteries of the Sunderbans. On this stretch alone you can see six different types of Kingfishers! A couple of pleasant hours later you arrive at the Sunderbans Jungle Camp on the Island of Bali. Here a sumptuous lunch awaits you and after a short rest in the well-appointed cottages we take you down to Sajnekhali, to see the Mangrove Interpretation Center and return via the Sudhyanakhali
Full day cruise.
After breakfast we transfer you back to Kolkata to connect flight back to Delhi. Arrive Delhi in the evening. Overnight stay Hotel
Tour ends. Transfer to International airport

tourName: Tigers of India photography tour
generalInfo:
Home to some of the world’s most diverse and vibrant ecosystems, India offers some of the best tiger viewing in the world. Embark on an 11-day wildlife photography journey through India’s Bandhavgarh and Kanha National Parks designed specifically for photographers seeking exceptional opportunities to capture the beauty and majesty of tigers in the wild, alongside other incredible wildlife species in their natural habitats.

With the guidance of professional wildlife photographer Karolina Norée, you’ll receive personalized photography tuition, tailored to your individual level of expertise. Whether you’re an amateur photographer keen to learn the basics or a seasoned professional looking to refine your skills, this tour offers an opportunity to elevate your photography in one of the most exciting environments on earth.

Along with the focus on photography, you’ll also gain a deeper understanding of wildlife conservation in these vital ecosystems, with the chance to learn from Karolina’s experience in both photography and conservation efforts. This tour offers more than just an opportunity to build a unique photo portfolio—it’s a chance to immerse yourself in some of the most exciting wildlife environments on earth, all while learning from an expert in the field and contributing to the ongoing efforts to protect and preserve these incredible habitats.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to India! Upon arrival in Delhi, you’ll be greeted and transferred to your airport hotel for a restful overnight stay. Take this time to relax, enjoy a hearty breakfast, and prepare for the exciting adventure that lies ahead.

Fly to Jabalpur in the early morning. From there, a scenic drive will take you to Kanha National Park, known for its dense sal forests and thriving tiger population. Check in at your lodge and head out for an evening drive to spot some wildlife.

Experience morning and evening safari drives in Kanha. This national park is famous for its Bengal tigers, Barasingha deer, and a rich variety of birdlife. Enjoy breakfast in the wild and evenings filled with sharing stories and savouring delicious local cuisine.

After an early morning safari in Kanha, embark on a scenic four-hour drive to Bandhavgarh National Park. Arriving in time for an afternoon safari, you’ll have the chance to explore the diverse landscapes and wildlife of Bandhavgarh.

Spend your next 4 days on morning and evening jeep safaris in Bandhavgarh Reserve. Capture stunning images of tigers, leopards, and numerous bird species. In the evenings, relax at the lodge, where you can share your experiences with fellow photographers over dinner.

Enjoy a final morning drive in Bandhavgarh before traveling to Jabalpur or Nagpur international airport for your evening flight home, carrying with you memories and photographs of India’s magnificent wildlife and landscapes.

tourName: Tigers safaris in India
placesVisited: Delhi, Kanha National Park, Nine tiger safaris, TOFT approved accommodation, Jabalpur, Other tiger watching safaris available in Bandhavgarh, Corbett or Ranthambore National Parks
generalInfo:
This tiger safari in India takes place in Central India’s Kanha National Park. This park is a wonderful mix of grassy plateaus, open misty plains and bamboo forests and is home to around a hundred tigers. As well as leopard, sambhar, chital and monkeys. After being met in Delhi, you will be transferred to a hotel for the night before taking a domestic flight to Jabalpur to start your safari holiday. All domestic flights are included in the price of your holiday.

This tailor made holiday is designed by a wildlife watching specialist operator and, in particular, wild cat safaris. As well as Kanha National Park, we can organise tailor made safaris to other national parks in India where there are tiger populations, such as Bandhavgarh, Corbett or Ranthambore. You will be accompanied by an expert local guide and will take at least five safaris within a park to maximise viewing opportunities.

We also recommend a night time spotting safari, although this is only possible in Panna and Satpura National Parks, using night vision equipment to spot tigers at night. In Satpura National Park you can also go on a walking safari but whichever way you choose to go in search of tigers, we will ensure it is an ethical experience, as we are member of the Tour Operators for Tigers (TOFT) and follow their strict codes of practice. We also stay in TOFT approved lodges along the way.

We are proud of our 100% sighting rate and of course, you will also get a chance to see a wide array of other wildlife, not just tigers. Please note that we are very happy to organise this trip for a solo traveller as well as for groups. The minimum age is eighteen.

The best time to go tiger watching in India is mid January to mid May. This is the hot dry season with the hottest time from beginning March until mid May. This is when tigers come out to waterholes to find water, or prey on other wildlife doing the same.

dayInfo.description: Delhi – Arrival – On your arrival in Delhi you will be met at the airport by your local driver and transferred in a private vehicle to your accommodation. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Kanha National Park – Travelling– This morning after breakfast you will be transferred to the airport to catch the short internal flight to Jabalpur. Here you will be transferred to your accommodation close to Kanha National Park. Tonight it is best to get an early night as you will be exploring the park on the trail of tigers early tomorrow. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Jabalpur – Sightseeing – This morning will see you have your 9th and final tiger safari into the park, if you have already seen tigers on the tour and wish to get better pictures of the other wildlife or want to try and find dhole we can accommodate different ideas today; but of course this is all up to you. Once you return to the accommodation you will have breakfast and pack your packs before being transferred back to Jabalpur. On arrival at the accommodation you can have lunch and in the afternoon you can take a cultural tour of Bhedaghat to see the Marble Rocks, Duandhar Falls and Chausath Yogini Temple as well as their being a river cruise of the Narmada River on offer. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Delhi – Sightseeing – Today after breakfast you will be taken to the domestic airport to catch the short internal flight back to Delhi. Once in Delhi you will be transferred back to the accommodation and you will have the rest of the day to relax, souvenir shop or sightsee around old and new Delhi. (Breakfasts, Lunches & Dinners included)
Home – Departure – This morning after breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (Breakfast only)

tourName: West central India wildlife holiday
generalInfo:
Nestled in West-central India, the lure of the Tiger at Tadoba and the fascinating undulating landscape at Pench is what drew us here many years ago in the pursuit of our love of photographing the stunning diversity of wildlife and game in what has come to be among the list of India’s best managed wildlife reserves on the sub-continent.

The etymology of Tadoba comes from the amalgamation of the tribal God Taru and the Andhari river that serves as the reserve’s water vein, filling it’s fresh water lakes during the brutal summer months.

Situated in the western state of Maharashtra, Tadoba’s wildlife fringes the local Gond tribal settlements around the region of Chandrapur. Traditional farmers and basket weavers, these tribes dwell in traditional village homes. Over the years we’ve cultivated a support system with these communities where we share with travellers what they do and how they carry on their process of living. We attempt to give back for our footprint in the region by supporting these communities by sourcing their produce and enlightening travellers about their culture and heritage.

It’s important to not just understand the rich bio-diversity of the park but also be made aware of the social conservation that inherently exists amongst these villages and their efforts in establishing a stable co-existence, especially within such close proximity, between man and wildlife in this region.

Pench on the other hand is situated in slightly hillier terrain over the border of Maharashtra and into the state of Madhya Pradesh in Central India.

Serving as an inspiration for Rudyard Kipling’s Jungle Book as home to Mowgli, it’s easy to see why Sir David Attenborough described Pench as the most appropriate location for documenting the behavior of Tigers in the wild.

Spread over an area of 750 square kilometres, Pench’s undulating terrain makes for a fascinating mix of plant species, rock caves and a fantastic diversity in woodland bird species.

But again, Pench is not just about the Tiger. In fact the excitement in pursuing unique species such as the four-horned Antelopes, wild dog packs, the elusive Leopards and the rather sly Indian Jackals.

With some of the best managed and regulated game drives within national Parks in India, the experience in Pench is of anticipation, intrigue and the satisfaction of being amidst nature in it’s best preserved state.

dayInfo.description: Transition to Tadoba: Using Mumbai as the international gateway, we’ll have you take a short hop domestic flight to the city of Nagpur from where you’ll travel overland to the village of Pet and your eco lodge by the river. The rest of this day is designed to be at leisure to settle in and shake off the long travel.

The Gond settlement of Pet and the wetland Birds: Beginning the day gently pedaling away to the village of Pet, on the fringes of Tadoba’s wildlife reserve, we’ll spend a good part of the day with these reticent tribal folk, observing their farming techniques, spending time with the women who weave baskets from forest produce and engage in conversation with them about how they supplement their sustenance with forest produce around them. Over the course of the late afternoon, you’ll head out for a walk with a Naturalist to hopefully get up close with the unique wetland birds, both resident and migratory that make their way to these parts.
Transition to Pench National Park: Leaving the Gonds and tigers of Tadoba, we’ll head north to the undulating mountains of Pench National Park.
Return to Nagpur and a night in Mumbai: Heading south to Nagpur, you’ll return to Mumbai to spend the night in preparation for your flight back home.

tourName: Western Ghats wildlife tour in India
generalInfo:
Running along the western edge of the Deccan Plateau in the states of Karnataka and Kerala, the Western Ghats mountains separate the Deccan Plateau from the narrow coastal plain which runs along the Arabian Sea.

This is the setting for one of the 36 world’s designated “hottest biodiversity hotspots”. This region supports an astonishing 5,000 species of flowering plants, around 140 mammals, over 500 birds and nearly 180 amphibians, many of them threatened. More importantly, this hotspot is home to great endemism including about 20 endemic mammals. Among flagship mammals, the most prominent are the Lion-tailed Macaque, found in highly fragmented tropical rain forests of the Western Ghats and the endemic Nilgiri Tahr, which lives in the montane grasslands of the Western Ghats. Over 30 species of birds are endemic or near endemic to this region and this tour will also seek to see them all.

On this journey, you will also be sighting the other major wildlife like the Asian elephants, Sloth Bears, Dholes and possibly the big cats. Commencing at Thattekkad and circumventing the Western Ghats at Munnar, the Anamalai hills, the Nilgiri Hills, the dry deciduous and scrub forests at Bandipur and Chinnar and finally the magnificent forests of Nagarhole, you will be accompanied at all times by a knowledgeable local naturalist who knows where to find the most elusive species. Travelling by SUVs or mini buses, comfortable specialist accommodation throughout and memorable local cuisines, all add to the experience.

The journey also will take you through tribal lands of Indigenous people – like the Muduvans of Munnar area, the Malapulayas of Chinnar and the Kattunayakan of Mudumalai – and share their tribal way of life and closeness to nature.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Kochi International Airport & transfer to Thattekkad – an area with extensive lowland forests and several types of eco-systems – riverine, grasslands, evergreen, scrub, dry deciduous, lowland forest, enabling it to be one of the best wildlife and birding destinations in India and home to some of the endemic mammals of the Western Ghats. The wildlife includes Indian Flying Fox, Malabar Giant Squirrel, the elusive Slender Loris, Indian Giant Flying Squirrel, Travancore Flying squirrel and the Common Palm Civet. This is also a great place for endemic birds, butterflies & odonata. You should see White-bellied Treepie, Rufous Babbler, Crimson-backed Sunbird, White-bellied Blue Flycatcher, Wynaad Laughingthrush, Malabar Parakeet, Malabar Grey Hornbill and owls which could include Mottled Wood Owl, Oriental Bay Owl, Oriental Scops Owl, Brown Fish Owl and Spot-bellied Eagle Owl. Sri Lanka Frogmouth, Red Spurfowl, Grey Jungle Fowl, Indian Pitta, Black-throated Munia and the Grey-headed Fish Eagle are all likely.

Today you will be moving to the hill country at Munnar - the highest areas along the Western Ghats. Among its rolling grasslands and steep cliffs live the endemic and endangered Nilgiri Tahrs. Concerted efforts by the conservationists have brought this magnificent animal back from the brink of extinction. At present there are more than 700 Tahrs in the area. The highlights would be a visit to the Eravikulam National Park area in search of this mild natured animal and as well as a trip to the Pampadum Shola – to look for the endemic Nilgiri Marten, Nilgiri Langurs, Malabar Giant Squirrel and endemic birds like the Nilgiri Wood pigeon, Nilgiri Pipit, Painted Bush Quail, Nilgiri Wood Pigeon, Black-and-Orange Flycatcher, Nilgiri Flycatcher, White-bellied Shortwing and the Broad-tailed Grassbird.

A longish travel day today as we head downslope to Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary. Here on your walk, look out for the endemic Grey Tufted Langur (or Madras Langur) and the near-threatened Grizzled Giant Squirrel, besides Star Tortoise. There are good chances of other wildlife like elephants and gaurs. Special birds to look out for include Yellow-legged Buttonquail and White-naped Woodpecker, Brown Fish owls and Spot-bellied Eagle Owls. After Chinnar you will be taking the 2 hour drive across the Tamil Nadu border to the forests of Valparai near Indira Gandhi national park - a place known for its great swathes of forests and wildlife. Elephants, sloth bears, leopards, gaurs, dholes (wild dogs) but the focus will be on the endemic Lion-tailed Macaques (on IUCN’s Red Data list for being a threatened species) which can be spotted in the high altitude rain forests here, their natural habitat.
