Another long drive will take you to Ooty in the mountains. Here also there are chances of sighting of the Nilgiri Marten if missed earlier. The target birds here include the Nilgiri Thrush, the Nilgiri laughing Thrush, White-bellied Shortwing, Black-and-rufous, Rusty-tailed and Nilgiri Flycatchers. The century-old Botanical gardens and the Cairnhill Forest reserve are the other places visited during stay here.

You will be making your way to a tiger reserve sanctuary within the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve – Bandipur, located between the Mudumalai Sanctuary on one hand and the Forests of Wayanad on the other. Devoted to conserving the endangered Tiger Habitat you also get to see endemics birds like Malabar Parakeet, Malabar Lark and Grey-headed Bulbul at the foothills of the Nilgiris. Seasonal streams along with the river Kabini are watering holes for the abundant wildlife of the region. You will also be going on two vehicle safaris into the Bandipur Tiger Reserve. Look out for the abundant wildlife here which includes large population of wildlife including Elephants, Sloth Bears, Four Horned Antelope, Hyena, Wild Dog, Common Langurs, Tigers, Leopards, Chital, Mouse Deer, Spotted Deer, Jackal, Porcupine and Mongoose and with some luck the big cats including the tiger and leopard. Accommodation would be at the Bandipur Safari Lodge belonging to the renowned Jungle Lodges & Resorts. (2 Jeep safaris)

Transfer to one of the best wildlife destination in South India – Nagarhole. The place derives its name from Kannada - "Naga" meaning snake and "hole" referring to streams. The area was an exclusive hunting reserve of the former rulers of Mysore. It was set up in 1955 and is one of the best-managed parks in the country. This park is located to the northwest of Bandipur National Park. Kabini reservoir separates this park from Bandipur National Park. The climate is tropical, summers are hot and winters are pleasant. The park boasts of a healthy Tiger-predator ratio. Tigers, gaurs (Indian Bison) and Elephants are much denser here than in other reserves in South India. In fact this National Park is the best destination for viewing tigers and Asiatic elephants in large numbers during the four vehicle safaris during your stay here. The amazing wildlife in this area also includes Hyenas, Dholes (Wild Dogs), Sloth bears, Common Langurs, Leopards, Mouse Deer and Spotted Deer.
After morning safari, transfer to Bangalore for your flight home.

tourName: Wildlife holiday in Central India
placesVisited: New Delhi, Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve, Kanha Tiger Reserve, Pench Tiger Reserve, Satpura Tiger Reserve, Bhimbetka cave paintings, search for: giant squirrels, tigers, leopards, wild dogs, water birds and wetland wildlife
generalInfo:
India wildlife tours are an amazing treat for nature lovers and for anyone else with a passing interest in adventure as they conjure up an incredible variety of experiences, least of all the chance to spot tigers, leopards, sloth bears, bison and crocodiles within a range of stunning environments.

As this particular 12 day India wildlife tour is exclusive you'll be able to take advantage of an array of luxury safari camp accommodation, with the tiger reserves of Kanha, Bandhavgarh and Pench all providing some exquisite scenes to accompany a range of comfortable facilities.

Aside from the wildlife tours, India is blessed with a bounty of ancient sites of interest with the UNESCO listed Bhimbtka caves providing a fascinating finale to this fabulous India wildlife tour.

Below are just a few of the highlights that you can expect to find whilst undertaking this private India wildlife tour:

- Big cat safari tours in India's most prestigious tiger reserves with excellent chances of seeing sloth bears, leopards and other wildlife alongside the slinking figure of Shere Khan himself.
- Explore Central India's best regarded jungle regions which are known to be the inspiration behind Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book.
- Take a guided tour of Satpura Tiger Reserve either on foot or by boat.
- Experience an array of chances to go bird watching and embark on nature photography trips.
- Find out more about the 30,000 year old cave paintings within the caves of Bhimbetka.
- Enjoy comfortable and well-equipped luxury safari camp accommodation.

dayInfo.description: New Delhi – Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve: Arrive New Delhi and catch morning flight to Jabalpur. At Jabalpur airport you will be met by your driver and driven to Bandhavgarh. Five hour drive (200 km) through rural India will take you to the forest of Bandhavgarh. Check-in to your lodge which is nestled comfortably in the lap of nature just on the edge of Bandhavgarh. Drain the day’s exhaustion with hot and cold beverages. Retire early after dinner, gearing up for tomorrow’s adventure.

Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve: World renowned Bandhavgarh is known for its high tiger density and thus offers the best chance to see tigers in the wild. Set out in search of world’s most elusive cat on 4x4 in morning and evening game safari.

Pench Tiger Reserve: Travel west from Kanha to Pench (200 km/5 hours). On arrival, check into your camp and relax amidst its natural setting. Designed in keeping with the local culture, the camp showcases a pastoral jungle theme. Named after the Pench river, the reserve is located in the southern reaches of the Satpura hill range. It also has some of the highest deer/antelope density in India attracting good numbers of carnivore such as tiger, leopard and wild dogs along with occasionally seen Indian wolf. Pench is the original setting which inspired Rudyard Kipling for his master piece ‘The Jungle Book’. BBC also brought Pench in international spot light after shooting award winning documentary ‘Spy in the Jungle’. Explore Pench in morning and evening game safari in search of wildlife.

New Delhi: Today after final morning jungle activity, bid farewell to Satpura and drive to Bhopal (150 km/3 hours). Pause 45 kms south of Bhopal to see the extraordinary cave paintings at Bhimbetka. The paintings at this UNESCO site are believed to be up to 30,000 years old. After Bhimbetka continue to Bhopal airport to catch flight to New Delhi/Mumbai for your onward journey.

tourName: Wildlife holiday in North East India
generalInfo:
Eastern India is one of the most biodiverse areas of the world; an area rich in forests, river systems and grasslands all bursting with wildlife. Some iconic and crictically endangered such as tigers, Asiatic elephants, Indian one-horned rhinos and others smaller and regionally endemic such as sunbirds, frogs and primates like Gee's golden langur and western Hoolock gibbon.

This tour explores some of the most famous and best wildlife watching locations in north-east India. These include the vast mangrove wetland ecosystms of the Sunderbans, the lush grasslands of Kaziranga and Manas as well as the seldom visited forests of Hoolongopar Gibbon Sanctuary.

For anyone interested in exploring some of India’s wildest and most remote national this is the tour for you.

Introduction:

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching tours and safari holidays all over the world, specialising in the Indian subcontinent and of course the wonderful and diverse country of India. Whilst most wildlife watchers who visit India spend time in the famous tiger reserves of the central plains or maybe the sub-Himalayan parks of the north west and Western Ghats in the south. But these ecosystems and incredible wildlife are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the wildlife that India has to offer.

This tour explores some of the lesser known parks and takes you into the deepest parts of India’s north eastern rainforests, mangroves and grasslands . All of this whilst escorted by our very own expert zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) coupled with local guides. Of course there is one species in particular that dominates everyone’s thoughts and dreams when they think of an Indian safari and that is the beautiful tiger.

Whilst there are chances of seeing tigers here we take time to showcase the tiger’s ecosystem in full and try and find as many other animals that share the forests with tigers. We also offer a few different ways of exploring the parks, so however you like to travel through the tiger’s habitat we have the tour for you, whether you want to drive around in your own jeep, walk through the forests and grasslands tracking the elusive big cat or even via a boat or canoe in the water ways of the Sundarbans.

One of the reasons why our safaris of India are unique is that our background (as a company) is from a scientific and zoological standpoint and so have a great network of colleagues and contacts all over the world who are the people on the front line in search of the best new locations for wildlife watching in the wild. All of these reasons and many more make us experts in arranging and guiding safaris and are able to tailor a Indian safaris to any location to try to find them that you request. All you have to do is to get in touch with us and tell us your budget and your group size and where you would like to go on safari.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner - where mentioned in the itinerary). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned vehicles with an excellent local driver for all transfers. We include internal flights where ever possible on all our Indian safaris. We use two brilliant full time guides; first a professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) will escort you on all your excursions and also a very knowledgeable English speaking local guide at each national park. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort is an expert in mammal biology, ecology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort has spent time studying and working with different species all over the world and he has years of experience guiding throughout most of India’s national parks. We also use local expert guides with decades of experience on all our Indian safaris. We also include all jeep safaris, guided walks, canoe safaris, boat-trips, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more individual safaris into national parks per tour than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the national parks to search for tigers and other wildlife. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on tigers and other Indian wildlife which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

March and April is the dry season and best for wildlife. For wildlife watching in southern India we recommend visiting during March and April (this is the best overall game viewing in the Indian Subcontinent’s main tiger reserves and national parks). This is towards the end of the hot dry season and offers the best chances of seeing wildlife as the hotter and drier it gets the more the wildlife aggregate around waterholes as well as there being less vegetation blocking the view.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our Indian safaris are guided by a local naturalist guides, drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife your watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We use camera traps (where available) which will increase the chances of getting close up pictures and movies of tigers and other rare nocturnal wildlife.
• During this tour we explore various national parks and wildlife sanctuaries (Sundarbans, Kaziranga, Manas and Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary) which will give you a very good overview of the wild Eastern forests of India.
• Travel into wonderful and world's largest mangrove forest of the Sundarbans in search of tigers, river dolphins and enormous slat-water crocodiles.
• By joining one of our Indian safaris you will have an overall wildlife experience as we are determined to showcase all of the wildlife of the parks we visit (not just tigers), you will not feel like a passenger in a rally and bounce all over the place in pursuit of tigers; we make sure all our Indian safaris are relaxed and environmentally friendly experiences. In fact the majority of tiger sightings that we enjoy in India are of tigers that our jeep and guides have found (as opposed to other operators who wait for a tiger to be seen and then stake out the waterhole surrounded by dozens of other jeeps), we always investigate any suspicious behaviour exhibited by their prey and usually find tigers by watching the deer and monkey behaviour as they change from relaxed to agitated when a predator is spotted.
• We have explored all the areas we visit in depth and have found the best and most conveniently located accommodations to stay in whilst searching out wildlife in isolated and remote places. Including some of the best and most ecologically friendly lodges in all of India.
• We are a member of Tour Operators for Tigers (TOFT) and we make sure that all of our tiger safaris run by their code of practice and we also make sure that all the accommodation we use is audited by TOFT to make sure of sustainable practices.
• All the above reasons give this our tiger tours and general wildlife holidays of India a great success rate of seeing tigers (100% in Bandhavgarh and close to 50% for this tour, which is very good considering the dense forests and vastness of the protected areas).
• We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout the India and are able to find and observe species that are difficult to find or overlooked sometimes such as Indian leopards, Asiatic elephants, water buffalo, sloth bears, jungle cats, dhole, gaur and hundreds other endangered, rare or endemic species throughout the tigers current distribution.
• Due to our greta network of guides and researchers throughout India we are able to organise tailor made safari to anywhere in India, whether it is Bandhavgarh, Kanha, Periyar, Kaziranga, Corbett, Ramthambore, Satpura, Tadoba, and many other wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari holiday to India.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour takes you to the eastern states of Bengal and Assam all from the city of Kolkata where you will enter and leave India. The parks visited include the Sundarbans, Kaziranga, Assam and Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary.

Fitness Level:

The fitness level required for this safari holiday is not very high. The vast majority of the activities are conducted from vehicles so no fitness is required, but there is some walking involved. The walking is all done at a leisurely pace with regular breaks, anyone who is used to mild hiking will find this easy.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 18 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Kolkata - Arrival & Birding On your arrivak into Kolkata you will be met by your local guide and driven to your hotel. Then after checking in and depending on your arrival time you will be taken to Chintamani Kar Bird Sanctuary. Here attractions include birds like Orange-breasted Green Pigeon, Emerald Dove, Streak-throated Woodpecker, Orange-headed Thrush, Lineated Barbet, Tickell’s Thrush, Greater Racket-tailed Drongo, Slaty-legged Crake, Little Spiderhunter and Blue-throated Flycatcher. The recently rediscovered Large-billed Reed Warbler was found at the edges of the Sanctuary. In addition, the sanctuary also hosts some small wildlife; namely Jungle cat, Indian Civet, Asiatic Jackal and a few other mammal species. (no meals included today)

Sunderbans - Travelling Early this morning, you will be transferred from Kolkata to Sunderbans and reaching the jetty in time for your afternoon cruise into the Sunderbans. Whilst we travel to the camp, located on an island in the mangroves we will be birding and watching for crocodiles and mammals throughout. On reaching the eco resort we will check in and relax for the rest of the day. (breakfast and dinner included)

Kolkata - Travelling Early this morning you will start your transfer back to Kolkata with the boat transfer back to the jetty from the resort. You will have breakfast onboard the boat. Once you arrive back at the jetty you will be transferred back to Kolkata and your hotel. The afternoon is free at your leisure. (breakfast is the only meal included).

Jorhat - Travelling Early this morning, you will be taken to a new birding location nearby Kolkata, here some range restricted species. From there you will be driven to the airport to connect to your flight to Assam (~2 hours). Upon arrival at Jorhat, you will be met by the driver and local guide and be taken to the tea estate for the next couple of nights. After checking in you will have the afternoon to enjoy the sylvan surrounds and a possible short walk in the estate. The estate has its share of wilderness; leopard, Asiatic elephant and jungle cat have been sighted here. Afterwards you will have your evening meal at the bungalow. (breakfast and dinner included only)

Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary - Wildlife Watching After breakfast this morning you will be driven to the only dedicated primate sanctuary in the Indian Subcontinent for a walk with a local guide looking for the endangered Western Hoolock Gibbon, Malayan Giant Squirrel, Capped Langur, Stump Tailed Macaque, Pig Tailed Macaque and other animals and birds. The place is full of thick forests with creepers and undergrowth and here one might see the Red Headed Trogon, Snowy Browed Flycatcher, Ferruginous Flycatcher, Lesser Shortwing, Grey Bellied Tesia, Slaty Headed Tesia and many other species of birds. After the morning gibbon watching and birding you will be stopping at a place inside the sanctuary for the packed lunch. After lunch you will continue searching forest for wildlife, including one of the only ape known from the Subcontinent. We have a choice of accommodation whilst exploring the Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary, firstly for anyone interested in seeing the rare and elusive Bengal slow loris there is a single government run guest house (Forest Rest House) in fairly livable condition inside the forest – those interested to see the Slow Loris will need to spend the night inside the sanctuary. Where after dinner a short walk for about an hour might reveal a Loris. However the decision regarding the stay has to be done prior to coming at Gibbon and the permission for the night walk has to be secured from the authorities – so we would need to know at the time of booking. The best time for the Loris is February – though it is sighted in other months too. For anyone not wanting to stay here we will leave the sanctuary towards sundown and drive back to other accommodation. (all meals included today)

Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary / Kaziranga National Park - Wildlife Watching Early in the morning (by taking a picnic breakfast with us) we will leave and visit the sanctuary again to explore it on foot, once again our main targets are the Stump Tailed and Pig Tailed Macaques and the Western Hoolock Gibbon. Other species are Malayan Giant Squirrel, Hoary Bellied Squirrel, Slow Loris, Capped Langur, Asiatic Elephant, Wild Boar and with luck a Leopard Cat. There is a wealth of bird life from the reserve too, species of note include Longtailed Broadbill, Silver Eared Mesia, Speckled and Rufous Piculet and several species of hornbills and with a bit of luck even the Hooded Pitta. The resident herd of Asiatic Elephants usually starts moving around this section of the sanctuary by the afternoon; so to avoid a potentially dangerous encounter on foot in the dense forest we will be leaving the sanctuary by lunch time and then drive to the Kaziranga National Park (2.5 hours) in time for an afternoon jungle safari. You will check in quickly and then hop on to your jeeps for the safari. Kaziranga is one of the most popular national parks in the whole of India, there are more large mammal species found here than anywhere else in the Indian Subcontinent including huge numbers of Indian one-horned rhinos, Asiatic elephants and healthy populations of tigers, water buffalo and other rare species such as Gangetic river dolphins. After this afternoons safari you will return to the lodge for your evening meal. (breakfast and dinner included today)

Manas National Park - Travelling & Wildlife Watching After breakfast you will depart from Kaziranga National Park and drive to Manas National Park. On arrival at your new lodge you will check in and then in the afternoon enjoy a safari to the park. The ecosystem of Manas is spread between Bhutan and India with protected national parks on both sides of the border. The targets include some of India's most elusive and endangered mammals, birds and reptiles. These include Crab-eating Mongoose, Hog Badger, Fishing Cat, Himalayan Crestless Porcupine, Leopard Cat, , Wild Buffalo, Assamese Macaque, other mammals include the Malayan Giant Squirrel, Hoary Bellied Squirrel, Smooth Coated Otter and the Indian One Horned Rhinoceros and the Asiatic Elephant. Birds include Rufous Necked Hornbill, Swamp Francolin, Black Tailed Crake, Hodgson’s Bushchat and Bengal Florican and the reptiles include the rare Assam Roofed Turtle. You will return to the lodge for your evening meal in the evening. (breakfast and dinner only included today)

Kolkata - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning you will have one final morning safari in Manas National Park before returning to the lodge for breakfast and then traveling to Guwahati to catch your flight to Kolkata (2 hours) you will then be taken to your hotel for your final night in India. (breakfast is the only meal included today)
Home - Departure After breakfast you will be transferred to the international airport in time to catch your return flight home. (breakfast is the only meal included today)

tourName: Wildlife photography holiday in India
placesVisited: Delhi, Kanha National Park, 11 game drives, Expert wildlife photography guide
generalInfo:
A ten day wildlife photography where you will travel around Kanha National Park, in the Central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, home to about a hundred of India’s tigers, as well as leopard, sambhar, chital, monkeys and the rare swamp deer. This itinerary includes eleven game drives in Kanha with an expert naturalist guide to accompany you, and one who has experience of leading internationally renowned wildlife photographers through these unique habitats. Habitats that range from large swathes of native sal tree forests, to open grasslands or bamboo bush. Making this the most perfect terrain for wildlife photography holidays with plenty of chances for magnificent sightings.

A large part of Kanha National Park has also been designated as Kanha Tiger Reserve, following pioneering conservation work known as Project Tiger in 1974. You will be staying in a luxury eco lodge, with all meals, game drives, park fees, guide fees and naturalist fees included.

Note: An extension to Agra is available to see Taj Mahal or Keoladeo National Park for some great Birding.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi & transfer to hotel. Local sightseeing arranged on request if time permits. Overnight hotel.
Sightseeing in Delhi, the capital city of India. Afternoon train to Jabalpur by AC sleeper class. Overnight train.

Reach Jabalpur early morning. Transfer to hotel for breakfast, freshen up. Later we drive to Kanha National Park (3hrs drive), check-in at lodge. Evening game drive. Kanha is an amphitheater of extreme delights that is how naturalist writers often describe this magnificent tiger landscape in Central India. The habitat comprises of grasslands, dense mixed and pure Sal forests and bamboo. Intervening rivulets, big and small makes the landscape charismatic and a joy to experience. The land of the tiger is home to more than hundred and supports wide variety of fauna and floral diversity. It is the best place in the wild to see the majestic Bengal tigers. The reserve is ideal for bird watching as more than two hundred and fifty species can be seen during the various seasons.
Kanha NP. Morning & evening game drive
Return to Jabalpur. Today after breakfast we drive back to Jabalpur for lunch. Later we board a direct overnight train to New Delhi, packed dinner onboard.
Arrive Delhi. You reach Delhi early morning & transfer to airport for your onward journey or transfer to hotel if you have booked extra nights. OPTION OF FLIGHT AVAILABLE INSTEAD OF TRAINS

tourName: Wildlife tour of India
generalInfo:
India is one of the top 5 bio-diverse nations and also the only nation in the world to have both tigers and lions. Experience the wildlife of India on open jeep safaris, nature walks and get an opportunity to spot a varied species of animals and birds across various national parks of central and west India. The most important species that you would get an opportunity to spot are the Tigers, Lions, Leopards, Deers, Boars and a plethora of species of birds including horbills, eagles, beeeaters, rollers etc. We also cover a tinge of Indian heritage by visiting the highlights of New Delhi and Agra including the mesmerising Taj Mahal.

The prominent experiences are highlighted below:

1. Explore the national parks of Central India (Kanha and Bandhavgarh National Park) that are amongst the best in the world for sighting the Royal Bengal tiger on open jeep safaris.
2. Explore the jungles of Sasan Gir National Park on open jeep safaris – only wild habitat of Asiatic lions in the world. There is a good chance of spotting Leopards as well in this park
3. Explore Delhi on a sightseeing tour – Visit Heritage monuments and old markets on a cycle Tour
4. See the heritage monuments of Agra – Taj Mahal, Agra Fort and Fatehpur Sikri – All World Heritage Sites
5. Experience the vibrant and cosmopolitan mumbai on a sightseeing tour and see its highlights like UNESCO listed elephanta caves, CST, dhobi ghat, gandhi museum etc.

dayInfo.description: Arrive at New Delhi International Airport. Receive a warm welcome from our representative and get transferred to the hotel. On arrival complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

• After breakfast, proceed for a sightseeing tour of the city with your guide. • Drive past or if you wish you may visit Red Fort • Drive past or if you wish you may take a stop at Raj Ghat – the cremation site of Mahatma Gandhi. • Visit Agrasen ki Baoli (ancient water reservoir) • Visit Jama Masjid • Visit Chandni Chowk – ‘the Moonlight Square and enjoy a Cycle Rickshaw Ride which takes you through the narrow streets of the Chandni Chowk. • Visit Lakshmi Narayan Temple • Drive Past India Gate – The All India War Memorial • Also pass by the Rashtrapati Bhavan (formerly the viceroy's residence) and the Parliament House. • Enjoy a special lunch at a local restaurant. • Visit Humayun's Tomb • Visit Qutub Minar - A UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Early morning have an excursion to Agra. The drive from Delhi to Agra is 3 hours one way. On arrival in Agra, visit Taj Mahal and Agra Fort. Both these monuments are UNESO World Heritage Sites. After having lunch, we return back to Delhi. Evening at leisure.

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to Delhi Airport and fly to Jabalpur. On arrival receive a warm welcome from our representative and drive to Kanha National Park (130Km, 4-hour drive). On arrival complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.
Go for a morning and evening open Jeep Safaris in Kanha National Park and witness the mesmerizing flora and fauna in the wild. You have an excellent opportunity of spotting Tigers
Go for a morning and evening open Jeep Safaris in Kanha National Park and witness the mesmerizing flora and fauna in the wild. You have an excellent opportunity of spotting Tigers

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and travel to Bandhavgarh National Park (210Km, 5 hours’ drive). On arrival receive a hearty welcome from our representative. Complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

Go for a morning and evening open Jeep Safaris in Bandhavgarh National Park and witness the mesmerizing flora and fauna in the wild. You have an excellent opportunity of spotting Tigers as Bandhavgarh has amongst highest density of Tigers in the wild.

After breakfast check out from the hotel, travel to Jabalpur Airport (166Km, 4-hour drive) and fly to Mumbai. On arrival receive a warm welcome by our representative and get transferred to the hotel. Complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

After breakfast, go for the sightseeing tour of Mumbai city with your guide. • Visit Victoria Terminus – UNESCO World Heritage Site, • Visit Hanging Gardens, • Explore Mani Bhavan – where Mahatma Gandhi Stayed, • Take a stroll on Chowpatty (beach), • Roam in Kamla Nehru Park • Visit Elephanta Caves – the 5th-century caves near Mumbai.

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to Mumbai Airport and fly to Diu. On arrival receive a warm welcome and get transferred to the hotel at Sasan Gir National Park (2-hour drive). Complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

Go for the morning and evening safaris in Sasan Gir National Park in an Open vehicle and witness the King of Jungle – The Mighty Lion in its natural habitat. You also have got an opportunity to spot Leopards and other species of animals and birds.
After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to Diu Airport and fly to Mumbai to board the flight for your home town.

tourName: Tour of Indian Palaces & Tiger Safari: Agra, Jaipur, Kanha & Bandhavgarh National Parks
placesVisited: Delhi, Jaipur, Agra, Kanha National Park, Bandhavgarh National Park
generalInfo: A feeling of majesty overtakes you when you see historic palaces or view unencumbered wildlife in its natural habitat. Experience the nature and history of India on this custom tailored tour. Find the grandeur of sandstone castles casting a pink glow upon a city. Witness the splendor of tigers prowling through the grasslands and beneath the towering sal trees. From the luxuries of jungle resorts to the stunning architecture of historic observatories you will find the unparalleled beauty of India.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – Begin your India Adventure
dayInfo.description: The day begins with the whirling streets of Delhi coming to life. The scent of fresh spices eminates from the chai sold and happily sipped alongside the streets. Small motor and bicycle taxis fill the lanes along with the rickshaws that are famous for winding through the wide and narrow streets. The impressive mixture of the city’s rich history pushes against the modern buildings, cars, and commerce. Delhi’s past is displayed in the museums and ruins. The Red Fortress was once converted to British barracks and continues to stand with vibrant red colors, from the sandstone walls to the towers that bring a sense of majesty from its glory days during the Mughal dynasty in the 17th century. The walls extend over 54 feet tall encompassing the vibrancy of Delhi’s opulence within the large and quiet walls that hide the modern world away . You can also find the India Gate, a larch arch reaching over 126 feet high and built in 1931 as a war memorial. The wide and long stretch of road that leads to the monument allows you to also view the unending flame within the archway. You will have the evening to yourself able to enjoy the aromas of the famous mutton burra kebab near the old mosque as the marinated meat delicately lingers over charcoal.

dayInfo.title: Jaipur – Into the Pink Palaces
dayInfo.description: The day comes to life once again in the morning hours of Delhi. The aromatics of paratha , pan-fried bread, bring deliciousness to the morning air and are accompanied by the spice of chai tea. After breakfast your private transfer will meet you at your hotel. You depart the capital and make your way to the famous Pink City of Jaipur. You arrive in the afternoon and will settle yourself in the comforts of your hotel before you make your way through the city on a guided tour. The city was founded in the 18th century. The precious pink coloration stems from the use of sandstone to construct much of the Mughal city which was repainted in the 19th century. The vibrant hues and the people’s energy seem to collaborate giving an ebb and flow to the streets where rickshaws and buses rush by meandering camels. The Galta Monkey Temple is situated within the tranquil yet impressive surroundings nestled between two granite cliffs. Known for the natural fresh water springs and holy water tanks, the marvelous temple shimmers pink within the foothills and looks more like a palace than a temple. As you ascend the stairways and walk along the edges of the pools you hear hymns and chants, but also interspersed animal screeches. An abundance of monkeys run along the upper levels, speeding over towers and rails, resting on the domed cupolas, and sipping water from the pools. You notice locals feeding the monkeys nuts and fruits. Stunning landscape, opulent architecture, and now the incredible wilds all surround you.

dayInfo.title: Jaipur – Within the Shinning Past
dayInfo.description: The morning colors of the city shine along the old streets with verve and welcome. After breakfast your guide will meet you and tour you through the city’s opulent hues and history. The City Palace comprises marvelous courtyards, gardens, and buildings at the heart of the Old City, creating a lavish combination of Mughal and Rajasthani architecture. The incredible pink coloration of the Chandra Mahal glows over the open square. The tranquil complex brings a subtle contrast to the surrounding energy of the modern city’s electric streets. Adjacent to the palace is the tremendous Jantar Mantar Observatory. The interesting sculptures displayed within the courtyard were specialized astronomical tools and were constructed in the 18th century. Meander along the 14 structures to discover the range of their functions; the instruments are used for measuring time and tracking the stars. Each instrument was chiseled from stone and adds to the continued inspiring feelings emitted from the complex. The sundial reaches a peak of 90 feet tall. You can see its shadow moving every minute, capturing the swiftness of time and the impeccable imagination of the past.

dayInfo.title: Umaria – Within the Halls of History in Agra
dayInfo.description: The morning sun captures the Old City in its beautiful light once more before you set out for Agra and the exquisite architecture of the Taj Mahal. The structure is situated at the edges of a lush courtyard like a crowning jewel. The complex dates back to the 17th century and was built as a tomb for the wife of emperor Shah Jahan. The entire structure is made of marble, which accounts for the way the opulent walls and Moorish dome catch the changing light throughout the day. Standing at the entrance of the complex gives the structure an entirely new look. The garden is lush with manicured trees and bushes and lined with walkways and placid ponds. The water reflects the image of the Taj Mahal when the fountains aren’t trickling. The minarets rise over 120 feet tall with a backdrop of open sky. The central structure contains pieces of semi-precious stones that bring different colors to the floral carvings. There is a surreal quality to the building and the complex, where symmetry is highlighted and delicate light shines through the marble screens. In the evening you will venture into the comforts of a first-class night train to Umaria.

dayInfo.title: Bandhavgarh National Park �– Within the Wooded Hills
dayInfo.description: The Bandhavgarh National Park sprawls over 270 square miles in a mixture of wetlands and sal forest that spread over the Vindhyan Mountains. Your train arrives in the early morning and your private transfer takes you to your jungle resort in no time. The earthen aromas of lush leaves and wet earth mix with the scent of spiced tea. A guided game drive will take you out into the vast forest in search of the wild that is known to scour the trees and grasslands. The park is also home to the famous white tigers of Rewa. Declared a National Park in the late 1960s you will traverse the park on the windy roads that take you up to the 2,400 feet high summit where the old fortress continues to look out over the expanse of wild. Endangered vultures nest within the towers and ramparts of the old protectorate that is now overgrown with vines and roots. Statues of Hindu gods continue to mark the complex, some sit beneath branches and others are somewhat covered in moss. The fort itself is thought to be over 2,000 years old, where even the caves that dig into the mountain were manmade and used as stables. Now those very caves are home to an abundant bat colony that is vibrant in the evening. They swoop through the air in search of prey. Step along the sturdy stone pillars to find spaces that nature hasn’t yet overtaken. It adds to the fortress’ natural and constructed wonder.

dayInfo.title: Bandhavgarh National Park �– Tiger Tour
dayInfo.description: The jewel of the wild within the national park is the tiger. In the morning you will be met by your guide and vehicle, which turns out to be an elephant with a comfortable wooden saddle along its back. You make your way through the tall, thin sal trees in search of the famous, regal tiger atop your pachyderm ride. En route you notice a small brownish-furred figure amongst the trees and discover the barking deer. The males have short antlers used for fighting over territory or mates. If you’re lucky enough to hear one call, it sounds similar to a dog’s bark. Its ears twitch as your ride trundles through the forest until the deer disappears beyond the tree line. The elephant is intent and focused with every step, somehow elegant in its walk even with its lumbering size. When you come to a raised ridge your guide and the elephant abruptly stop. Prowling close by is the black striped fur of a tiger watching you come closer through the wild grass. You can make out its face between the blades but its body seems to blend in effortlessly. You watch the large cat but are sure not to challenge it by looking into its eyes. It soon decides that you are not a threat and rushes past leaving you, your guide, and the elephant behind.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – A New Jungle, a New World
dayInfo.description: When the morning light stretches over the jungle canopy you will depart from Bandhavgarh and make your way by private transfer to Kanha National Park. The afternoon sun reaches through the expansive forest of over 1,200 square miles where you can see the undulating mountain ranges covered in lush trees, rising up to 2,700 feet above sea level. The diverse topography comes from the Horseshoe Valley at the foothills of the Mekal Mountains where the Surpan River winds its way along the grasslands. In the evening you will set out on a game drive to explore the sensational nature when the wildlife awakens with vigor after the midday heat recedes. In the tall grass you can see the iridescent feathers of a peacock strutting through the blades. The elegant blue neck and swaying neon green tail radiate within the meadow offering new allure to the forest.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – Above the Meadows
dayInfo.description: The sounds of the morning come with a rush as you hear gaur , Indian bison, calling along the banks of the Surpan River. After breakfast you will once more climb aboard an elephant to explore the surrounding jungle regions of a tremendous nature reserve. On top of the animal’s back you sway with every step and watch the grasslands below, the trees above, and the vast expanse in front, while searching for leopards in the branches and tigers in the bush. Every now and then your elephant pushes aside a tree or brings up a sapling’s roots. It marks the path and spreads the seeds along the forest floor. Close by you find the graceful but skittish dhole , an Asiatic wild dog with red fur, a black tail, and a bark that sounds more like a whistle. It is easy to imagine an unaltered state of the forest, brimming with flora and fauna over the mountains and along the riverbanks. As you listen to the rambunctious chirp of the dhole you find awe in their playfulness with one another and in the surrounding rising grassland.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – Endless Splendor within the Trees
dayInfo.description: It is easy to imagine Rudyard Kipling traversing the forest on elephant-back in search of nature’s majesty and becoming inspired by the immense land, diverse plant life, and enduring wildlife. Kanha National Park is known as the inspiration for Kipling’s The Jungle Book and persists in its ability to awe visitors in the same way it once captivated the famous novelist. The day takes you out into the woods once more in search of the tiger, referred to as “Shir Khan” in The Jungle Book in reference to the tiger’s power and prowess within these lush lands. When you come across the tiger in the wild you find unquestionable beauty in its stride. You notice its black and faded orange tail curling under its hind legs. Each step it takes is slow and calculated, not wanting to waste any unnecessary energy. Adult tigers, especially males, are often solitary, so when you come across two tigers lingering at the edges of the river you will witness a rare moment when the cats display how relaxed and delicate they can be toward each. As the sunlight drifts across the sky you don’t want to pull yourself away from the extraordinary vision of the wild.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – Out of the Woods
dayInfo.description: In the morning you will wave goodbye to the mesmerizing nature of Kanha National park and make your way by private transfer to Jabalpur. Arrive in the early afternoon to enjoy lunch at the Hotel Krishna with the remainder of the afternoon at your leisure. The Rani Durgavait Museum houses an exceptional display of 10th century sculptures from surrounding local sites. Statues of Ganesh and tremendous stone reliefs bring detailed descriptions of historic devotion to light. On the upper level you can find letters and photographs in a gallery that explores tribal cultures in the region. In the early evening you will come to the train station and step onto your luxury first class car. You will be whisked through the Indian night en route to Delhi.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: You arrive in Delhi in the early hours surrounded once more by the fragrance of spiced chai filling the air with cinnamon and nutmeg. A private transfer will take you for breakfast before you make your way to the airport for your return journey home. You have spent your time within the historic shadows of Rudyard Kipling and the wondrous sal forest of Bandhavgarh National Park exploring the lavishness of the Indian landscape, wildlife, and the splendor where the two come together.

tourName: Wildlife Photography Tour of India: Kanha National Park, Jabalpur & Delhi
generalInfo: Capture your memories through India on this custom tailored tour that will take you through history, modernity, and the ancient wilds. Venture through the historic streets of Delhi where ruins stand and centuries-old buildings are still in use. Take an excursion into the forest where the wildlife will breathe new life into everything you knew India could be, from marvelous architecture to a rich tiger reserve. Ready yourself for splendor; all you have to do is make sure you focus your camera.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – A Photographic Start
dayInfo.description: Welcome to the capital city of India, Delhi, where the past and modern world combine in both architecture and culture. Your private transfer meets you at the airport and takes you to your comfortable accommodations. The remainder of the day is at your whim and pleasure. You notice the energetic streets of the city, awash with spiced aromas that drift from the chai stands down the walkways, and lined with people sipping their tea and talking. The colors are more vibrant than you ever could have imagined. Lightweight textiles and saris flow in the breeze and capture the colors of previously unknown depths of the rainbow. The city is rambunctious with energy, filled with rickshaws that can take you through the old street and along the gates of the historic market where the scent of fabulous cuisine, such as tikka masala, and the smoky charcoal of roasting kebabs are mixed with the vibrant display of textile stores. Your private guide can take you outside the city center to the Okhla Bird Sanctuary over Yamuna River. The area is known to have over 300 bird species. You can look out over the one and half square miles of river to see an Indian vulture circling the area with a wide and impressive wingspan that spreads an average of nearly seven-feet.

dayInfo.title: Overnight Train – A Full Day of Delhi
dayInfo.description: Your day begins with the delicate aroma of cinnamon and clove reaching through the streets as the sun drifts above the horizon. Your guide meets you after breakfast and you begin your day-tour through the city, its culture, and its tremendous past. The Rah Ghat is also known as the Gandhi Memorial, and commemorates one of the most notable people associated with the country. A park sits as the entrance area, filled with lush greenery and open space. Students tend to run around and relax along the grass. The central courtyard is adorned with a black marble memorial surrounded by ever-changing gardens. However, at the center of the marble, flickering inside what looks like a large lantern, is the eternal flame that represents the memory of Mahatma Gandhi. You continue your tour and the indulgent scent of kulle chaat entices you. The snack is a combination of hollowed out fruits that are filled with a blend of spices, lime juice, salt, chickpeas, and pomegranate seeds and brings a mixture of sweet, savory, and tart refreshment to your lips. You make your way through the twist of bazaars filled with rose petals to the shrine of Nizam-ud-din Auliya. It feels like you have stepped back through time to view a commemoration of the centuries. The site has become a place of pilgrimage, filled with the embodiment of the Sufi saint, along with the Urdu poet, Amir Khusru. The marble brings an opulent touch to the rousing singing of hymns that call out at sunset. Often filled with devoted followers and fans, you will notice the enthusiasm and charm on people’s faces as they visit with the ancient saint whose tomb is often covered with fresh flower petals that decorate the lavish yellow pillars and immaculate marble. In the early afternoon you will be taken to the train station where you will find your comfortable first-class car waiting to take you on an overnight journey to Jabalpur.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – Courtyards and Jungles
dayInfo.description: You arrive in Jabalpur in the morning and will have a private transfer out of the city and into the depths of the jungle at Kanha National Park. Come to your lodge found in the lavish forest. The enchanting boutique hotel brings a touch of India’s British Colonial past to the architecture and highlights the eco-friendliness of the complex. The pool looks out over the mixture of trees and grassland where you can dip your toes into the cool water with the afternoon heat on your shoulders while listening to the monkeys lingering in the nearby canopy. In the late afternoon, you will venture out into the jungle for an evening game drive, when the animals come alive in the fresher air of the disappearing sun. The reserve is known for its large population of tigers. As you traverse the immaculate grassland and tree lines of the surrounding wild you will be sure to keep your eyes out for bright orange fur combed with black stripes that has captivated your imagination and enthusiasm.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – Visiting the Wild throughout the Day
dayInfo.description: The early morning brings the cool breeze and the scent of spices mixing with the aromatic grassland. Before the sun has a chance to fully rise you step out into the surrounding woodlands with your guide to spend the day within the fabulous sal trees and tall grasses. The reserve stretches over 1,200 square miles of undulating country, from the flatland to the mountains of the Mekal Ridge that gives a horseshoe shape to the valley. A mountain peak rises over 2,700 feet above sea level. The wildlife is abundant and vivacious as you search through the collection of thin, tall trees, where the canopy rustles with Langer’s monkeys. The white fur of the monkeys stands out against the dark bark, and darker faces. You hear tigers roar in the distance and your guide attempts to chase the sound as it reverberates through the trees and your bones, a tremendous, powerful call. You may not find the tiger today but you do find the iridescent plumage of a roller bird along the thin tree branches. Its tail feathers shine a vibrant turquoise against the leaves as a blackbuck grazes in the tall grass nearby. The deer’s upper pelt stands out against its white underneath. Its textured horns twist away from its forehead. Kanha’s fauna brings endless splendor to the day, and as you return to the the lodge for the evening you will find the comforts of your room embracing.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – In Search of the Natural
dayInfo.description: Once more you will venture out to explore the depths of the flora and fauna within Kanha National Park. With your professional and seasoned guide you will traverse through the revving of early morning forest. Sloth bears are nocturnal but can be seen traveling through the woods within the early mixture of night and day. Their lanky build and shaggy coats create a mane around their face. Their lower lip has been adapted to dig for insects. The bamboo forest shapes the terrain as much as the rising mountains creating the valley. The scent of bamboo and sal are picked up in the breeze while the quiet atmosphere brings an echo to the rustling leaves. When you look into the trees you can see a branch dangling from an awkward angle. Soon you realize that it isn’t a branch but a tail, flicking lightly in the warm afternoon air. Able to leap more than 20 feet and capable of carrying an animal three times their own weight straight up a tree, the leopard’s nocturnal nature keeps them lazing about in the cool shade of the canopy during the day. You watch its tail swish along the branches and you can see the leopard’s elegant spots as well. As one of the most prolific cats, you cannot deny its stunning grace. In the evening upon your return to the hotel you can sit around the fire and listen to jungle tales that range from tribal dances with fabulous rhythms, to simple stories that have been passed down through the ages, adding mystery to the starlight and understanding to the relationship of animals and humankind.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – Discovering the Wildlife
dayInfo.description: When you find yourself within the beauty of nature, no matter the time of day, you can’t help but marvel at the serene landscape of the extensive grassland, oftentimes towering over the Indian bison that you see grazing in the distance. The forest canopy mixes sal and pakur trees and the foothills bring the bamboo thickets to abundance. You hear a hawk-eagle call in the sky, circling somewhere beyond the lush leaves that have overtaken the view. Cheetal deer groom one another along the riverbanks, their white spots glowing against their brown fur. Peacocks stand attentively on branches that overlook the tall grass and their chortle brushes through the blades. Their effervescent blue feathers look like a spotlight, standing out against the coloration of the landscape. The day brings another endless collection of wildlife along garnered memories, whether from your photos or from the pictures in your mind, all wrapped together with the tranquil sounds and abundant life of the park. Upon your evening return to the lodge you are certain that the following day will bring you close to the majesty of tigers.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park – An Elephantine Exploration
dayInfo.description: This morning you can experience Kanha a different way by scouring the plains and forest on the back of an elephant instead of in an open air vehicle. You climb aboard the pachyderm early in the morning and sit comfortably in a brass saddle covered with pillows. You already feel like the moment has accentuated your exploration of the wilds in India. Every second seems to be worth a photograph as your elephant steps with intent, able to traverse the dense forest, steep foothills, and tall grasslands without worry. The longer you travel through the flora, the more excited you become, as you scour the distance in search of the largest wildcat. Finally, you spot one, resting at the edges of a marsh with its paws dipped into the water. You have only imagined its exquisiteness, but up close you find that your images don’t measure up to what the tiger looks like in reality. Its coat glows in the afternoon light. It lounges against the comfort of the cool water. The black and orange coloration somehow blends into the grasslands around it. As the photos of the tiger hold strong in your camera and your mind, you continue through the forest, where you will come to the river where you can help your guide wash the elephant if you wish. Note: All interactions with wildlife planned with our travel experts are ethical and humane

dayInfo.title: Overnight Train to Delhi – Returning from Nature
dayInfo.description: Today you will awaken after the sun has risen over the forest canopy. Delight in the tastes and aromas of breakfast before you are met by your transfer and taken to the city of Jabalpur. You will enjoy a lunch at a hotel where the art deco décor brings a sense of the decadent past back to life, from the vivacious red façade to the restaurant’s youthful hues. The luscious scents of lunch, traditional Indian fare prepared by a master chef, is nothing less than a treat that welcomes you back into urban life. In the late afternoon, you will step into your first-class train car and begin your overnight return to Delhi.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – The Grand Streets Once Again
dayInfo.description: In the morning, your train arrives in Delhi, bringing you back to the energetic streets filled with capital life. You are taken to your hotel where you can relax with the rest of the day at your whim and pleasure, whether that means reclining on the rooftop terrace, watching the racing rickshaws and horse carts close to the old market, or venturing once more through the historical sites of the city to revisit the culture that you will soon leave behind. Jama Masjid is the largest mosque in the city and dates back to the 17th century under the Islamic Mughal Empire. Multiple entrances surround the sandstone walls that lead to the main worship deck. The area is often brimming with people who come both to pray and to witness the architectural integrity of the ancient mosque. Two minarets and a smattering of onion-shaped domes create a particular skyline as the scent of grilled cuisine lifts around the main entrance gates from a local restaurant nearby.

dayInfo.title: Delhi – Photographic Memories
dayInfo.description: The day brings with it the colorful stretch of sunrise that blends into the customary blue of the morning. After breakfast you will be met by private transfer and taken to the airport to catch your return flight home. From Delhi’s streets to the grasslands of Kanha National Park, you have commemorated your time in India with limitless photos and previously unimaginable memories. Soon you will find yourself at home where it is hard to believe that it wasn’t all just a dream, and you will already be planning to relive the wonders of India once more.

tourName: Wildlife Tour and Tiger Safari in India
generalInfo: Step into the incredible wilds of India on this custom tailored tour that will take you through the national parks and reserves known for their Bengal tigers. The streets of Delhi are vibrant and historic and the lush jungles of thin, towering sal trees stand alongside the graceful marshlands. Ride through the woodlands on the back of elephants as you scour the riverbanks in search of Asiatic wild dogs and the orange and black striped glow of the largest cat in the wild. From stunning architecture to unparalleled wildlife, you will find it all in India.

dayInfo.title: Delhi - Urban Safari
dayInfo.description: Welcome to the capital of India, Delhi, where the streets are dizzy with activity, filled with women in colorful saris. The clothing flows effortlessly in the breeze with the vivacious aromas of coriander and cinnamon. The palpable energy boosts you to readiness, eager to venture out and visit the city. Your private transfer will have you settled into your accommodation where the rest of the day is at your leisure to rest or explore, with your guide eager to help in any way. Once within the city you notice the endless activity in the streets. People sip chai on the corners and people form long lines in front of food-stands where the aroma of smoky charcoal adds succulence to the grilled meats. At Hauz Khas Complex you will find history wrapped in the ancient network of ruins, from a mosque to a once important water tank. Dating back to the 14th century, the water tank stored rainwater only to be used when necessary in the dry season. Around the stone ruins where columns support bulbous domes atop risen porticos, you can see local college students studying or relaxing between classes, giving a rebirth of modern life to the ancient stones.

dayInfo.title: Delhi - Tremendous Travel
dayInfo.description: The early half of the day is yours to explore more of Delhi at your whim and desire, following along the past and present streets that continue to bustle with life, movement, and color. Venturing through Delhi brings richness to the history and the current state of the city. At the Qutb Minar Complex you will find the first monuments erected by the Mehrauli sultans dating back to the 13th century. The sandstone coloration brings a depth of red to the tower that stands over 217 feet tall. The fluting fluctuates between angular and rounded bringing a variety of textures to the pillar. It is hard not to notice the Alai Darwaza Gate, the main gateway built in the 14th century. The dome brings a collection of red sandstone and white marble to the complex with latticed stone screens and is the first building in India to display Islamic architecture. The surrounding architectural park is filled with locals and visitors alike, some enjoying the beauty of the past while others simply come for the open space and stillness, away from the outer walls of endless vibrancy. In the late afternoon, you will transfer to the train station to climb into the first-class train car that will have you in Katni by morning.

dayInfo.title: Bandhavgarh National Park - Entering the Wilderness
dayInfo.description: In the morning light you can look out the window and find swaths of villages in the passing landscape, within the trees and open spaces in the distance. Disembark the train at Katni and be met by your private transfer who will soon have you comfortable at your resort housed in the marvelous wilds of Bandhavgarh National Park. The area that was hunting ground for the royals of Rewa became protected grounds in the late 1960s. Home to the famous and mythical white tiger, the park now encompasses over 278 square miles and is set within the Vindhya Mountain Ranges. In the evening you will venture out into the mixture of sal trees, bamboo, and grasslands; the landscape changes with the foothills and seasons. As you scour the trees and grasslands in search of the diverse animal population, the day’s warmth begins to dissipate and brings the fabulous wilds to life.

dayInfo.title: Bandhavgarh National Park - Finding the Jungle
dayInfo.description: The morning is filled with vibrant birdcalls just as the sun is peeking over the horizon’s greenery. The jungle is vivacious in the early hours. You are met by your private jeep and are ready to explore the magnificent nature once more. At the summit of the 2,433-foot tall mountain is a 10th century fort, once the stronghold known as Moti Mahal. From the height of the mountain and scouring along the ruin fortress walls, you can look out over the expansive jungle, even through the canopy to grounds below. Past the entrance gate you notice the walls overtaken by nature, shrouded with elegant vines and sprawling leaves. Man-made caves that once housed horses are now home to a thriving bat colony. Even within the once prominent fortress, the structure has been combined with the surrounding nature, not just within the foliage but also with the wildlife. Deer traipse through open space and nibble on the grass. Falcons swirl the air in search of food, and old statues lie beneath looming trees.

dayInfo.title: Bandhavgarh National Park - Orange and Black
dayInfo.description: Step out into the vast jungle, beneath the lingering shade of the fortress up high, in search of the majestic tigers that are known throughout the park. The jeep trundles through the unpaved pathways and vines dangle overhead. The scent of dry earth is pleasant in the cool early hours of the day. Vultures circle in the distance above the peak where the fortress is situated. You continue to scour the contrasts of desiccated and colorful grass. Your guide stops the jeep and quietly points into the distance. You can see a tiger laying its head down in a marsh overrun with thick grass. It laps at the blue pond water with calm strokes. The orange coat glows with sharp black stripes with patches of white along her underbelly. The moment is not just unique but unparalleled, giving you a look of the largest wildcat in its natural habitat. Soon the tiger finishes its drink and sets out into the grasslands disappearing within the jungle as quickly as it had appeared.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park - Within the Stories of Kipling
dayInfo.description: The flaky aroma of paratha , pan-fried flatbread, quickly fills the morning air. Today you will leave behind the quiet shadow of the sky-high fortress and make your way to the magnificent jungles of Kanha National Park. The park wraps around 121 square miles of sal forests, with large meadows and wild bamboo giving home to a vast number of diverse wildlife. You will also visit the location famous for being the inspiration for Rudyard Kipling’s The Jungle Book . The Halon and Banjar River flow eagerly through the park giving a sensual trickle sound throughout the woods. In the afternoon you will arrive at the Courtyard House where a quaint courtyard displays a fabulous mixture of both British and Indian architecture. It pays tribute to the land and local tribal elements allowing for a pristine atmosphere in the majesty of the wilds.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park - In Search of Khan
dayInfo.description: The Surpan River runs along the central grasslands beneath the foothills of the Mekal Ridge. The highest peak stands over 2,700 feet above sea level, overlooking the entire mixture of sal trees and meadows. As the day begins to drift over the horizon you venture out on a guided tour of the diverse ecosphere once more in search of the remarkable wildlife. The morning breeze brushes against your cheeks as you tour along the unpaved pathways beneath the thin tower of trees and beside the open grasslands in search of the regions most notable inhabitant, the tiger. As the biggest cat in the wild, the tiger can weigh over 700 pounds with a length of almost 11 feet. The scent of leaves and brush fills the air. The calm forestry is palpable with the independent birdcalls chirping sporadically in the silence. As you peer into the meadow along the warm afternoon you find a large male tiger relaxing in the shade of dangling branches out of the sun’s reach. His coat ranges from yellow to light orange with dark brown stripes stretched long on his body and decorating his face. The magnitude of the cat adds to its splendor. After you or the tiger move on, you will continue your exploration of the jungle to see more of the fabulous nature in action.

dayInfo.title: Kanha National Park - Ready for More
dayInfo.description: You, like Rudyard Kipling, have become mesmerized by Kanha National Park, filled with the exceptional life of wild dogs and deer, Indian buffalo and tigers. Today you will experience nature differently as your guide brings you aboard an elephant to explore the surrounding landscape. The compartment that sits on the elephant’s back sways back and forth like a boat as your ride steps with large, intent steps, taking you deeper through the trees. Now and again it strips the bark from the towering sals and you can hear the wood splinter into the air. Your guide brings you to the riverbanks where, within the meadow, you find a collection of deer. One of the animals proudly presents its large, splaying antlers which rise above the grassland. The serene image of deer grazing in the meadow near the water viewed from your position atop an elephant is a memory that you know will be treasured.

dayInfo.title: Overnight Train - Returning from the Jungle
dayInfo.description: The jungle ambiance is soon replaced with an atmosphere that takes you back in time within the comforts of a hotel in Jabalpur where you will enjoy your lunch prepared by a master chef. The dining room is elegant without being ostentatious while servers are attentive and caring. The room fills with the familiar aromas of the Indian dishes that you have delighted in over your journey. It also carries a refined quality within the presentation. From the art deco décor to the graceful plating, it is apparent that you are no longer in the jungle. In the afternoon you will step onto the Super Fast Train where a first-class room awaits you. The luxuries of the car give you a scenic window into the villages that pass. Colorful saris bring reds and blues to the grasslands and rolling hillsides until the countryside turns to a blur and the evening settles in.

dayInfo.title: Delhi - Another Arrival
dayInfo.description: The late morning brings you into the train station at Delhi, returning you to the capital amidst the grand architecture of both the past and present walls. You will be met at the station by your private transfer and taken to a restaurant for an enjoyable lunch within the sensational aromatics of spiced masala and ginger. The flavor, aroma, and effervescence of Delhi are catching, and will have you fondly remembering your time along the storied history within the city, and amidst the elegant nature. As you make your way to the airport you can’t help but picture a tiger lounging in the shade and an elephant careening through the forest. Your time within the wilds of India may have ended but the memories will always be close at hand.
